maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Microsoft System Center Core Monitoring Management Pack: This management pack contains the core monitoring for the System Center 2012 core platform and its services.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitor type to check for duplicate relationships between agents and servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Probe module type to execute a specific script to obtain a property bag.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitor type for checking the grooming and partitioning process.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rules report availability state changes about any System Center Management Health Service into database.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This section is not applicable to this notification rule.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: There is no resolution to perform for notification rules since they do not generate state or alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that the OpsMgr certificate is about to expire.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The OpsMgr Certificate is about to expire.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Import a new OpsMgr certificate.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The service principal name (SPN) for the "System Center Data Access" service may have failed to register. The "System Center Data Access" service must register SPNs for the Operations console and other SDK clients to authenticate using Kerberos.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: In most cases this is due to the "System Center Data Access" service not having the necessary permissions to perform the SPN registration within Active Directory.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the existing SPN registrations by running the following command:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Setspn.exe -L <MS NetBIOS Name>

maml:section.maml:para: If the SPNs are registered correctly, you should see the following results:

maml:listItem.maml:para: MSOMSdkSvc/<MS NetBIOS Name>
MSOMSdkSvc/<MS FQDN>

maml:section.maml:para: If the SPNs are not correctly registered, register them manually by running the following commands, using an account with domain administrator rights:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Setspn.exe -A MSOMSdkSvc/<MS NetBIOS Name> <MS NetBIOS Name>
Setspn.exe -A MSOMSdkSvc/<MS FQDN> <MS NetBIOS Name>

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that an AD Integration agent assignment rule failed to complete successfully because it was denied access to the domain. Agents will not find out which server they should report to until this problem is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Access was denied while adding members to the Security Group. The Run As account used by the rule lacks proper rights.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the groups were created with correct ACLs and that the account the rule is running under has access. One way to fix the ACL is to delete the Management Group container in the domain, using MOMADAdmin {Management Group Name} {Domain}, and re-run MOMADAdmin.exe to prepare the domain again. The agent assignment rule will detect that the container was re-built and attempts to re-create the objects with the appropriate permissions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that an AD Integration agent assignment rule failed to complete successfully because an important prerequisite is missing. Agents will not find out which server they should report to until this problem is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Operations Manager container or the container named after your management group does not exist in the domain. The container holds the Operations Manager service connection points and associated security group to be created by the agent assignment rule.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: See product documentation for AD Integration and run "MOMADAdmin.exe" before configuring agent assignment rules.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that an AD Integration agent assignment rule failed to complete successfully because no domain account is found to be a member of the Operations Manager Administrator User Role. Agents will not find out which server they should report to until this problem is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: At least one member of the Operations Manager Administrators User Role needs to be a domain security group and provided as parameter to MOMADAdmin in order for the AD based agent assignment rule to function properly.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Add the security group, which was provided as parameter to MOMADAdmin.exe, to the Operations Manager Administrators User Role.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that an AD Integration agent assignment rule failed to complete successfully because it cannot bind to the specified domain. Agents will not find out which server they should report to until this problem is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The agent assignment rule is unable to bind to Active Directory. This may have been caused by:
1. AD may have become inaccessible.
2. The run as profile (default = Active Directory Based Agent Assignment Account) used by the rule does not have a valid run as account that can access the management group container in the domain.
3. The run as account associated with the run as profile has wrong user name or password.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: 1. Make sure all servers in the AD Assignment resource pool are able to access the domain.
2. If the Run As Account is a domain user account, make sure the username and password is valid.
3. If all else fails, then try deleting the Management Group container in the domain, using "MOMADAdmin -d {Management Group Name} {Domain}", and re-run MOMADAdmin.exe to prepare the domain again.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An error occurred while attempting to update the management group container(s) in Active Directory that are used for AD integration.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This rule runs on a server in the AD Assignment resource pool and uses the default action account. Review the alert details to identify the event that triggered the alert. The most common causes are access denied and connectivity issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Examine the error message provided in the supporting events to identify the underlying issue(s). A web search on the specific error message may provide help with troubleshooting the problem. Ensure that the action account for the AD Assignment resource pool has sufficient privileges to access the Active Directory container. Confirm that all servers in the AD Assignment resource pool have connectivity to the domain where the container is located.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: For information on Active Directory integration, see Use Active Directory to Assign Computers (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=194447).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the version of agents and generates an alert when it detects a 32-bit agent installed on a 64-bit operating system. Running a 32-bit agent on a 64-bit operating system will produce unreliable results and is not a supported configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The agent installed on the computer specified in the alert is the incorrect version for the operating system. This may occur when the agent is installed manually.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: On the computer specified in the alert, remove the Operations Manager agent manually by using Programs and Features in Control Panel. You can then reinstall the agent, either by using the Operations console (recommended) or manually. If you install the agent manually, ensure that you install the correct version of the agent for the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on installing agents, see:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks the version of agents and generates an alert when it detects that the version of an installed agent is older than the version specified in the monitor configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The version of the agent installed on the computer specified in the alert is older than the version specified in the monitor configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Upgrade the agent to the latest version.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor raises an alert when the Operations Manager agent cannot resolve Secure Reference overrides that are defined in the management packs.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Operations Manager agent uses an asynchronous distribution mechanism for delivering accounts that are referenced by the management pack secure reference overrides. Distributing configuration changes in the overrides among multiple computers might take a few minutes. During this time, the accounts remain inaccessible, making the Operations Manager agent log an event indicating that the accounts referenced by Run As Profile cannot be resolved.

With properly configured account distribution, a separate event is logged after all referenced accounts are delivered to the monitored computer. The second event will not be logged while there are remaining unresolved secure reference overrides.

This monitor tracks these events and raises an alert when the Operations Manager agent does not receive the accounts referenced in Run As Profiles in a configurable timeframe (the default time is 5 minutes).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you receive alerts from this monitor, you must verify the RunAs account configuration. Open the Run As Profile specified in the event delivered by the alert, locate the Account entry as specified by its SSID, and then either choose to distribute the Account to the computer if appropriate, or change the setting in the Profile so that the target object does not use the specified Account.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor measures the Process\Handle Count utilization for the Health Service process. If it exceeds the configured threshold, a recovery attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service to ensure it doesn't continue to overwhelm the computer.
There are different thresholds depending on the role that the System Center Management Health Service is configured to perform. The following summarizes the default thresholds:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:para: Below is the configuration for the recovery that attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A brief summary of potential causes are:

maml:entry.maml:para: Too many rules and monitors are loaded from all the management packs this System Center Management Health Service has been configured with.
A misconfigured rule or monitor collecting too much data or processing too much data (e.g. performance counter collection rule collecting data every 1 second)

maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the System Center Management Health Service running many management packs. Each Management Pack may have a lot of monitoring that uses a small amount of resources. With many management packs that add up to many thousands of rules and monitors, the System Center Management Health Service may start consuming more resources.
This may be expected for this System Center Management Health Service depending on the type of monitoring the System Center Management Health Service is performing.

Another cause could be one or more rules and monitors that are not conforming to some best practices. An example is a performance counter rule that attempts to collect performance data every 1 second. Too many rules or monitors configured this way will cause the System Center Management Health Service and it related process to consume more resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The default action for this monitor running on agents is to restart the System Center Management Health Service. Because this recovery is enabled by default on agents, no user action is required.

If you still see this monitor in a critical state, the System Center Management Health Service may not have restarted correctly or the action account this agent has been configured with does not have the right permissions to restart the service.
If this is the case, start the System Center Management Health Service windows service.

The hotfix provided in Knowledge Base article 968760 can correct some issues that result in this monitor changing to a critical state. Ensure that the hotfix from Knowledge Base article 968760 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=196234) has been installed on any computers that are using too much memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor measures the Process\Private Bytes utilization for the Health Service process. If it exceeds the configured threshold, a recovery attempts to restart the Health Service to ensure it doesn't continue to overwhelm the computer.
There are different thresholds depending on the role that the Health Service is configured to perform. The following summarizes the default thresholds:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:para: Below is the configuration for the recovery that attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A brief summary of potential causes are:

maml:entry.maml:para: Too many rules and monitors are loaded from all the management packs this System Center Management Health Service has been configured with.
A misconfigured rule or monitor collecting too much data or processing too much data (e.g. performance counter collection rule collecting data every 1 second)

maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the System Center Management Health Service running many management packs. Each Management Pack may have a lot of monitoring that uses a small amount of resources. With many management packs that add up to many thousands of rules and monitors, the System Center Management Health Service may start consuming more resources.
This may be expected for this System Center Management Health Service depending on the type of monitoring the System Center Management Health Service is performing.

Another cause could be one or more rules and monitors that are not conforming to some best practices. An example is a performance counter rule that attempts to collect performance data every 1 second. Too many rules or monitors configured this way will cause the System Center Management Health Service and it related process to consume more resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The default action for this monitor running on agents is to restart the System Center Management Health Service. Because this recovery is enabled by default on agents, no user action is required.

If you still see this monitor in a critical state, the System Center Management Health Service may not have restarted correctly or the action account this agent has been configured with does not have the right permissions to restart the service.
If this is the case, start the HealthService windows service.

The hotfix provided in Knowledge Base article 968760 can correct some issues that result in this monitor changing to a critical state. Ensure that the hotfix from Knowledge Base article 968760 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=196234) has been installed on any computers that are using too much memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule measures the Process\Handle Count utilization for all instances of the Monitoring Host process. If it exceeds the configured threshold, a response attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service to ensure it doesn't continue to overwhelm the computer.
There are different thresholds depending on the role that the System Center Management Health Service is configured to perform. The following summarizes the default thresholds:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:para: Below is the configuration for the response that attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A brief summary of potential causes are:

maml:entry.maml:para: Too many rules and monitors are loaded from all the management packs this System Center Management Health Service has been configured with.
A misconfigured rule or monitor collecting too much data or processing too much data (e.g. performance counter collection rule collecting data every 1 second)

maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the System Center Management Health Service running many management packs. Each Management Pack may have a lot of monitoring that uses a small amount of resources. With many management packs that add up to many thousands of rules and monitors, each Monitoring Host instance may start consuming more resources.
This may be expected for this System Center Management Health Service depending on the type of monitoring the System Center Management Health Service is performing.

Another cause could be one or more rules and monitors that are not conforming to some best practices. An example is a performance counter rule that attempts to collect performance data every 1 second. Too many rules or monitors configured this way will cause the monitoring host.exe process to consume more resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The default action for this rule running on agents is to restart the System Center Management Health Service. Because this recovery is enabled by default on agents, no user action is required.

Note that the System Center Management Health Service may not restart correctly if the action account that this agent has been configured with does not have the right permissions to restart the service.
If this is the case, start the System Center Management Health Service windows service.
If you feel that the resource utilization is appropriate for the amount of monitoring being performed by this agent, you can override the threshold or disable the rule.
