maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that can be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects data for the System\System Uptime performance counter.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if an event that is logged periodically is not detected. The rule associated with this monitor is "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event". If you disable the "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event" rule or configure too high of a threshold, it may cause this monitor to change state or generate an alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to enter a error state when the expected event is not detected within 45 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused if there is problem logging events to the Windows Event Log or if there is a problem reading and collecting this event from the Event Log.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check if there are any script errors in the Operations Manager event log for the LogEndToEndEvent.ps1 script. This script logs the event that this monitor detects.

If there is no script error, check if there are any errors with the Windows Event Log Module having problems reading from the Operations Manager event log; this may be caused by the Action Account not having permissions to either write to or read from the event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if an agent is unable to log or collect an event. The rule associated with the unit monitors is "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event". If you disable the "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event" rule or configure too high of a threshold, it may cause the unit monitors to change state or generate an alert.
To view additional context and state change information, please navigate to the error or warning unit monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor can enter a non-healthy state when an event expected to be collected from each agent fails to be collected or is delayed for a long period of time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if an event that is logged periodically is not detected. The rule associated with this monitor is "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event". If you disable the "Log Distributed Workflow Test Event" rule or configure too high of a threshold, it may cause this monitor to change state or generate an alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to enter a warning state when the expected event is not detected within 30 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused if there is problem logging events to the Windows Event Log or if there is a problem reading and collecting this event from the Event Log.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check if there are any script errors in the Operations Manager event log for the LogEndToEndEvent.ps1 script. This script logs the event that this monitor detects.

If there is no script error, check if there are any errors with the Windows Event Log Module having problems reading from the Operations Manager event log; this may be caused by the Action Account not having permissions to either write to or read from the event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule runs for each System Center Management Health Service and logs an event. This event is collected and used to verify that the end-to-end workflow to collect events properly is functioning as expected. If you alter the interval for this rule, it can cause the corresponding monitors to change state or generate an alert. The corresponding monitors are "No End to End Event for 45 Minutes (Critical Level)" and "No End to End Event for 30 Minutes (Warning Level)".

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The agent installer service already exists.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This service is installed to initiate and monitor the installation of the agent on the target computer machine. If this service already exists, an installation could already be underway or the service was orphaned during a failed install or uninstall of the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure there is no other pending installation on the target computer. If you suspect that the service was orphaned from a failed installation, delete the service. You can use sc.exe that is available on WinXPSP2, Windows 2003 SP1 Server, or the Windows Resource Kit.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The agent installer service failed to start after installation.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The agent installer service is used to initiate and monitor the agent installation on the target computer. If it fails to start, the Management Server will not be able to install the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the System event log on the target computer for details as to why the agent installer service was unable to start up.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The remote agent installation failed to complete.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by various reasons.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the agent management installation logs to determine what failed. Under the Management Server install directory there is a folder for failed agent installations. The installation logs may provide enough information to determine what failed. The installation logs are located in the Agent Management\Agent Logs sub directory of the installation folder. Example using the default installation paths:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the event log on the target computer where you were attempting to remotely install the agent.
Look in the Application and Security event log for any errors that may indicate why the Management Server was not able to remotely install the agent.
Fix the errors.

maml:section.maml:para: You may also need to check the Management Server Application and Security event log.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The remote agent installation failed to complete and there were no agent management log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may occur when the Management Server fails to install the agent and the Management Server was not able to pull back the agent management installation logs.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Find and fix errors.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the event log on the target computer where you were attempting to remotely install the agent.
Look in the Application and Security event log for errors that may indicate why the Management Server was not able to remotely install the agent.
Fix the errors that you find in the log file.

maml:section.maml:para: You may also need to check the Management Server Application and Security event log.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Unable to verify the version of the remote computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when the Management Server has limited access to the machine. The account used to remotely install the agent may not be an administrator but have elevated rights (for example; Power User).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the Action Account or alternate credentials supplied in the Discovery Wizard has administrative rights on the target machine.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This roll-up monitor rolls up health for any of the monitors indicating an agent management action failure. Below are a list of agent management actions:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Push agent installation
Uninstall agent
Agent repair

maml:section.maml:para: If any of the above fail, one of the monitors under this roll-up monitor will have a critical state. The unit monitor that has the critical state will an alert and knowledge on how to resolve that issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server failed to remotely install the Agent Installer service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may happen when there is a problem with the Service Control Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the System event log of the target computer from the Service Control Manager. Resolve any problems found in the event log.
Retry remote agent installation via the Discovery Wizard.

maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server failed to perform an operation on a remote computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This alert can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A specific alert for an agent installation failure (for example; Windows Installer service is not running)
An unknown or generic error

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check installation logs in the Management Server install directory. There is a folder for failed agent installations. These logs may provide enough information to determine what failed. These logs are located in the Agent Management\Agent Logs sub directory of the installation folder. Example using the default installation paths:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the event log on the target computer where you were attempting to remotely install the agent.
Look in the Application and Security event log for any errors that may indicate why the Management Server was not able to remotely install the agent.
You may also need to check the Management Server Application and Security event log.

maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Remotely installing the agent failed due to IP Address resolution failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: While performing a remote agent installation, the Management Server attempts to resolve the name supplied by the IP Address that we directly connect to. If this fails, the Name Resolution service used on the network might not be working.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The following troubleshooting steps can be used to diagnose the problem. You should perform these steps on the Management Server that your were connected to when the User Interface was running the Discovery Wizard and attempting to remotely install the agent.
Perform an nslookup on the target computer name. If not IP address is returned, try using a different DNS server.
Example of nslookup using the target computer name from the command line: nslookup [ComputerName]
nslookup dc1.contoso.local
Example of nslookup using a different DNS server: nslookup [ComputerName] [DNSServer]
nslookup dc1.contoso.local dns1.contoso.local

If the above doesn't result in an IP Address, you may need to change the DNS configuration on the Management Server to ensure it can resolve the IP Address of the computer you are attempting to install the agent to.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The target computer does not meet the minimum MSI version required to install the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The minimum MSI version (3.1v2) is not installed on the target computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Install the latest version of MSI.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The name supplied by the user in the Discovery Wizard does not match the NetBIOS computer name that was verified against the remote computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: There is a stale DNS entry.
The NetBIOS cache on the Management Server that attempted to install the remote computer is corrupt or out of date.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: 1. Perform the following steps on the Management Server that the User Interface is connected to:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open a command prompt from: "Start" menu, then "Run", type "cmd.exe" and click OK or press Enter.
Type "ipconfig /flushdns" and press Enter.
Type "ipconfig /registerdns" and press Enter.
Type "nbtstat -RR" and press Enter. Note: RR must be in upper case.

maml:section.maml:para: 2. Install the agent through the Discovery Wizard.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The management server failed to establish a DCOM connection to the remote computer where you are trying to install an agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when there is a firewall or IPSec policy that only allows specific ports. Since DCOM uses a dynamic port range, you may not be able to remotely install an agent unless an exception is added to the firewall policy on the target agent. If you are not using a Host based firewall, you may need to add an exception to your network-based firewall between the IP Address or host name of the target computer (and all computers you want to remotely install an agent to) and the management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Add a firewall exception to allow all ports between the target computer and the management server.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server failed to connect to the remote computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Although the Management Server was able to successfully resolve and discover the computer, when attempting to connect and remotely install the agent the Management Server failed to establish any type of network connection to the remote computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Connect to the computer using the following tests:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Ping the remote computer.
Connect to the remote computer using the Computer Management MMC snap-in.
Remote Desktop into the remote machine.

maml:section.maml:para: Note: Be sure to do this from the Management Server that was attempting to remotely install the computer.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server task that remotely installs the agent was interrupted.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service is being shut down while a remote agent installation is already in progress.
The Data Access service was being restarted while submission of the task was happening.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure the System Center Management Health Service and System Center Data Access service are up and running. Also check the Operations Manager event on the Management Server your User Interface was connected to and check for any errors with the System Center Management Health Service or Data Access service.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The operation timed out when attempting to remotely install the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when the target computer is low on available system resources (for example; CPU, memory, Disk I/O).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the target computer to see if any other process is consuming a large amount of CPU or memory.

If there is nothing that seems to be consuming the CPU or memory, open Performance Monitor and check for Physical Disk\% Idle Time. If this is below 10% for a long period of time, there may be some other process thrashing the physical disk.
Retry to remotely install the agent when the target computer is not so busy.

maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A reboot is required to complete the installation of the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This happens when there is a file that is locked while the agent was being installed.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To process the Pending File Name Operations, restart the operating system.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server was unable to obtain an exclusive lock on the Registry.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when another Management Server is also attempting to install the agent or when anti-virus or other spyware detection software has locked the registry for its scan or quarantine feature.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that only one Management Server is attempting to remotely install the agent. If you are sure that there is only one server that is pushing an agent, temporarily add an exclusion to your anti-virus software or spyware software to exclude the MOMAgentInstaller.exe process during the installation.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Remotely Opening the Service Control Manager on the target computer failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The account that is being used to connect to the remote computer does not have the right permissions and is being denied access.
There is a problem with the Service Controller Manager.
There is a firewall or IPSec policy between the Management Server and the target computer where you are attempting to install an agent.
If there is a firewall or IPSec the ports required to communicate to the Service Controller Manager may be blocked. These ports are 135 and 137 through 139.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the account used to install the agent has the right permissions on the remote computer. This account may be the default action account or it may be the account supplied in the discovery wizard.

Ensure there is no firewall or the appropriate firewall and/or IPSec policy exceptions are in place on the target computer. Additionally, check the System Event Log on the target computer to ensure there are no errors from the Service Controller Manager.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more services required by the Management Server to remotely install the agent are not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: To remotely install an agent, the following services are required to be started on the target computer:

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If any of the above are not running or their Start Type is set to Disabled, start them up and run the Discovery Wizard again.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Server failed to connect to an administrative share.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the following problems:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The remote computer does not have any remote administrative shares (they may have been removed).
The Server windows service may not be running on the target computer.
The Workstation service may not be running on the Management Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the target computer had Administrative shares.
To view them:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Computer Management MMC snap-in on the target computer.
Expand "Computer Management", then "Shared Folders", then click the "Shares" folder.
In the list of shares, look for shares that end with a "$". Example: C$, Admin$. These shares are used by the Management Server to connect and copy down the agent installation files.

maml:section.maml:para: The administrative shares are created when the Server service is started. If you do not see the Administrative shares, you can recreate them by restarting the "Server" service on the target computer.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The target computer that you attempted to install to does not meet the minimum operating system version.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: You attempted to install to a remote computer that doesn't meet the minimum operating system requirements.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Refer to the supported configuration guide for the list of operating system versions that are supported.
Upgrade the target operating system to the latest service pack or operating system required to install an agent.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows Cluster Virtual Servers are discovered and automatically managed when an agent is installed on each physical node on the cluster.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The computer you supplied in the Discovery Wizard is a Windows Cluster Virtual Server.
You supplied a computer that is the Network Name of a Windows Cluster Virtual Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To monitor the Virtual Server, you must install an agent on each physical node in the cluster.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Windows Installer service is disabled on the target computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Windows Installer service is disabled.
To remotely install an agent, the services Start Type needs to be set to "Manual" or "Automatic".

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Change the "Start Type" of the Windows Installer service to "Manual" or "Automatic".
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data from the Service Control Manager when the System Center Management Health Service fails to start.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data from the Service Control Manager when the System Center Management Health Service starts successfully and enters a running state.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data from the Service Control Manager when the System Center Management Health Service is terminated unexpectedly.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Invalid value used with alert configuration while overriding alert properties.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Information about the failure is available in the associated Event.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Replacing value defined for parameter in alert configuration failed and as a result, alert description may not be properly displayed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Information about the failure is available in the associated Event.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details to diagnose the problem.

maml:entry.maml:para: First, to troubleshoot this issue, please locate workflow ID inside of event description.
Then look for this identifier in management packs downloaded to agent experiencing such problem.
In the case this comes from sealed management pack, disable this workflow and notify management pack provider/developer.
In the case this comes from unsealed management pack, update tag with correct XPath.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule detects failures to generate alerts due to bad parameters in the alert settings of a rule or monitor, which prevent the rule or monitor from running.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A parameter for a rule or monitor is incorrect or missing.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: In the details for the alert, identify the rule or monitor that has the bad parameter. If the rule or monitor is in an unsealed management pack, change the implementation of the rule or monitor to resolve the parameter problem. If the rule or monitor is in a sealed management pack, use overrides to modify or disable the rule or monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events about failures that occur when a rule or monitor attempts to generate an alert and one or more parameter replacement actions fail. If these events are being generated then there is a problem with the way the rule or monitor has been authored. Since these events are also being monitored by alert generating rules, this rule is disabled by default to reduce on the data collected. This rule can be enabled for investigation purposes but should otherwise be disabled. Events collected by this rule will show in the "Health Manager Events" view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Replacing value defined for suppression in alert configuration failed and as a result, suppression of active alert cannot be achieved as expected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Information about the failure is available in the associated Event.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details to diagnose the problem.

maml:entry.maml:para: First, to troubleshoot this issue, please locate workflow ID inside of event description.
Then look for this identifier in management packs downloaded to agent experiencing such problem.
In the case this comes from sealed management pack, disable this workflow and notify management pack provider/developer.
In the case this comes from unsealed management pack, update tag with correct XPath.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Alerts generated within defined interval has exceeded allowed amount and as a result, rule was temporarily suspended.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Information about the problem is available in the associated Event.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details to diagnose the problem.

maml:entry.maml:para: First, to troubleshoot this issue, please locate workflow ID inside of event description.
Then look for this identifier in management packs downloaded to agent experiencing such problem.
In the case this comes from sealed management pack, disable this workflow and notify management pack provider/developer.
In the case this comes from unsealed management pack, adjust workflow configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Syslog module failed, therefore no syslog messages can be processed on this System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated event and alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events generated by Syslog module that can be used in either reporting or a view to diagnose issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more rules or monitors are trying to access a log in the Application Log Module but they failed to do so. They will continue to attempt to access the log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Rules and Monitors may fail to access an event log for one of the following reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The event log is corrupt or not present on the system.
The rule or monitor has been configured with the incorrect name of the log.
The Operations Manager action account does not have access to the event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Look at the name of the Application Log Module provided in the alert context.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Use the computer management task to connect to the computer, and confirm that the event log is present and accessible.

Confirm that the name of the event log shown in the computer management snap-in is the same as what was shown in the alert. If that is not the case then update the workflow to use the correct name of the log.
More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event context. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Application Log module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
A runtime error occurred during initialization. Check the event for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Application Log module:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Average Threshold module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated event.
The cause of the failure could be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
The specified computer could not be reached. The associated event description contains the specific error.
Insufficient credentials for operation. The associated event description has more information.
The specified performance counter information was invalid. The associated event description contains the specific error code.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.
This could be either:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Correct the erroneous configuration element from the error event.
Provide correct credentials or fix network issues that might prevent the remote computer from being accessed.
Verify whether the counter information is correct, and whether it can be sampled using Performance Monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A script that was running as part of a converted management pack encountered an error and failed to complete successfully. The alert description contains detailed information about the workflow that generated this error.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by a number of reasons such as:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The error was present in the MOM 2005 management pack
The script does not handle certain error conditions

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The script should be edited to handle the error condition appropriately. You will receive a single alert per object and workflow for this issue. If the script contains multiple errors and you fix the first occurrence you will not see subsequent alerts until the original alert is closed since the alert is suppressed per workflow and object.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Baselining Module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated event.
The cause of the failure could be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
The specified computer could not be reached. The associated event description contains the specific error.
Insufficient credentials for operation. The associated event description has more information.
The specified performance counter information was invalid. The associated event description contains the specific error code.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.
This could be either:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Correct the erroneous configuration element from the error event.
Provide correct credentials or fix network issues that might prevent the remote computer from being accessed.
Verify whether the counter information is correct, and whether it can be sampled using Performance Monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operations Manager Agent could not run a command or script as part of a rule or monitor due to insufficient system resources.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Too many scripts or commands are being run by the agent.
Scripts or commands are taking too long to execute.
Scripts or commands are running too frequently.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example: memory) to run the command or script.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. However, there may be other rules or monitors failing as well. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the command or script:
After reviewing the error in the context, consider reducing the frequency of the script or command.
Ensure that the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.

maml:section.maml:para: This can also be caused when too many simultaneous processes are being scheduled to run. This could be the result of an event storm or a misconfigured timer. In both cases the rule configuration will have to be examined to determine why the script is running too often and usually will need to be changed by for example increasing the script interval.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service was attempting to run an executable and was unable to create the process.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The executable could not be found.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example; memory) to run the executable.
The script extension is not properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the path to the executable exists on the computer.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.
To ensure that all script extensions are registered, follow the steps in the “Let me fix it myself” section of Knowledge Base article 949140 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181825).

maml:section.maml:para: Note that if the executable could not be found, the rule is misconfigured. Open the rule was executing the response and update the rule configuration with the right path to the executable or install the executable on the target system.
Lastly, you should check the working directory and application file path for errors and also verify the action account has access to the application/directory.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service was attempting to run an executable and was unable to create the process.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The executable could not be found.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example; memory) to run the executable.
The antivirus software on the computer blocking Visual Basic scripts or Java scripts. The following link is a link to the KB article regarding this issue.
The script extension is not properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the path to the executable exists on the computer.
The antivirus software is not blocking scripts from running.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.
To ensure that all script extensions are registered, follow the steps in the “Let me fix it myself” section of Knowledge Base article 949140 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181825).

maml:section.maml:para: Check the error information in the event or alert context for the script path and name. There could be a problem with the script not handling an error correctly and exiting. If the script exits without outputting the data that is expected (e.g. property bag data), this error is raised.
Another error can be caused by the misconfiguration of the workflow executing this script. The configuration (script parameters, policy, timeout) could be wrong causing no output or timeout.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager was attempting to run a script or executable and was unable to create the process.
This may affect some monitoring.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The executable could not be found.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example: memory) to run the executable.
The antivirus software on the computer blocking Visual Basic scripts or Java scripts. The following link is a link to the KB article regarding this issue.
The script extension is not properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the path to the executable exists on the computer.
The antivirus software is not blocking scripts from running.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.
To ensure that all script extensions are registered, follow the steps in the “Let me fix it myself” section of Knowledge Base article 949140 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181825).

maml:section.maml:para: Check the error information in the event or alert context for the script path and name. There could be a problem with the script not handling an error correctly and exiting. If the script exits without outputting the data that is expected (e.g. property bag data), this error is raised.
Another error can be caused by the misconfiguration of the rule or monitor executing this script. The configuration (script parameters, policy, timeout) could be wrong causing no output or timeout.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The port for the Customer Experience Improvement Program (CEIP) is currently being used and Operations Manager is unable to transmit CEIP data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The port that CEIP is configured to use is currently in use. The default port for CEIP is port 51907.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To change the port for CEIP, disable client monitoring, and then re-enable client monitoring using the Client Monitoring Configuration Wizard and specify a different port. For instructions on configuring client monitoring, see Configure Client Monitoring in Operations Manager 2012 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=161804).
To display the active connections being used by the TCP/IP protocol, at the command prompt, type “netstat –b”.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM has received a bad URL request while listening for Vista/CEIP clients.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: While listening for Vista error reports or CEIP reports, AEM received an invalid URL request. This can happen due to several reasons. For instance, it can happen if there has been a security threat or the protocol has changed between Vista/CEIP clients and AEM.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert is a warning to notify that an invalid URL request has been received by AEM. If this happens repeatedly, please contact Microsoft Customer Service and Support.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: On communicating with the Microsoft Watson Service, AEM encountered a timeout.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When a Error report/related cab was transmitted to the Microsoft Watson service, AEM encountered a timeout. This may happen due to several reasons. A few being that the Watson Service is down or there are other network issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert is a warning alert to note that a response to an Error Group report could not be retrieved due to a communication timeout. If this happens repeatedly, please check your network and/or contact support.microsoft.com with the error information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM encountered an error while processing the Error Report and/or related CAB for an error group/system error group, causing AEM to abandon the processing step.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates a generic [system] error group processing failure. This may happen due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM is not able to access the file share that has been configured for collecting error reports from various clients.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: File share is not reachable from this Management Server by AEM. This may happen due to several reasons. It can happen if the file share is not online any more or there are ACL issues. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem. To fix access issues, Client Monitoring Action Account's run as account needs to be added to AEMAgent group. Execute 'AEM: Fix Permissions' task associated with Crash Listener entity on this Management Server. Once this issue is fixed, either restart the System Center Management Health Service or re-enable Client Monitoring for this Management Server.

Try executing the 'AEM: Fix Permissions' task against the Crash Listener entity on this Management Server. The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to further diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: On communicating with the Microsoft Watson Service, AEM received an invalid response.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When a Error report was transmitted to the Microsoft Watson service, the service response could not be comprehended. This can happen if the Watson service may have changed the protocol to be incompatible with AEM.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert is a warning alert to note that a response to an Error Group report was invalid. If this happens repeatedly, please contact support.microsoft.com or Watson.Microsoft.com with the error information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The web proxy configuration on this Management Server is invalid. AEM cannot transmit any error reports to oca.microsoft.com and watson.microsoft.com

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The web proxy settings are not configured correctly for this Management Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Verify your proxy settings on this Management Server and change if required. Test that the Management Server can connect to oca.microsoft.com and watson.microsoft.com.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: On communicating with the Microsoft Online Crash Analysis Service, AEM received an invalid response.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When CAB file for a System Error Group was transmitted to the Microsoft Online Crash Analysis (OCA) service, the service response could not be comprehended. This can happen if the OCA service may have changed the protocol to be incompatible with AEM.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert is a warning alert to note that a response to a System Error Group report was invalid. If this happens repeatedly, please contact support.microsoft.com or oca.microsoft.com with the error information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One of the components of AEM could not start. As a result, AEM will not be processing error reports.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

To fix access issues, Client Monitoring Action Account's Run As account needs to be added to the AEMAgent group, given access to the database and also needs to be given access to the URL for listening to Vista error reports.

For the first part, execute 'AEM: Fix Permissions' task associated with Crash Listener entity on this Management Server. For the second part, use httpcfg.exe (http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa364478.aspx) for configuration (like, httpcfg.exe set urlacl /u http://+:[portNumber]/ /a D:(A;;GX;;;[SID]) and GetSid.exe (http://support.microsoft.com/?kbid=926027) to get SID for the Client Monitoring Action Account.
Once these issues are fixed, either restart the System Center Management Health Service or re-enable Client Monitoring for this management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events generated by AEM modules that can be used in either reporting or a view to diagnose issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One of the components of AEM could not start. As a result, AEM will not be processing error reports.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem. To fix access issues, Client Monitoring Action Account's run as account needs to be added to AEMAgent group, given access to the database and also needs to be given access to the URL for listening to Vista error reports. For the first part, execute 'AEM: Fix Permissions' task associated with Crash Listener entity on this Management Server. For the second part, use httpcfg.exe (http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa364478.aspx) for configuration (like, httpcfg.exe set urlacl /u http://+:[portNumber]/ /a D:(A;;GX;;;[SID]) and GetSid.exe (http://support.microsoft.com/?kbid=926027) to get SID for the Client Monitoring Action Account. Once these issues are fixed, either restart the System Center Management Health Service or re-enable Client Monitoring for this Management Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM encountered a network communication error while communicating with oca.microsoft.com and/or watson.microsoft.com.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates a generic network communication failure. This may happen due to several reasons. The ports may not be open for communication. The proxy may be misconfigured or this may be caused due to other network issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM has encountered a parameter for an error group containing characters considered invalid by AEM and will move these set of reports to Invalid Data folder on file share.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: AEM has encountered a parameter for an error group containing characters considered invalid by AEM: ~!@#$^&*()=+[]{}|;`",<>/?. Information about the error group and parameter is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the parameter/error group is valid, add the parameter name in Exception Folders list via SDK class: Microsoft.EnterpriseManagement.Monitoring.ClientMonitoring.AemGlobalSettings. Once this is done, copy over the data from InvalidData\Cabs, InvalidData\Counts to Cabs and Counts folders respectively on the file share for processing.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: AEM does not have enough permissions to communicate to watson/oca services/Operations Manager database.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates a generic network/database permissions failure. This may happen due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: On communicating with the Microsoft Online Crash Analysis Service, AEM encountered a timeout.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When CAB file for a System Error Group was transmitted to the Microsoft Online Crash Analysis (OCA) service, AEM encountered a timeout. This may happen due to several reasons. A few being that the OCA Service is down or there are other network issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert is a warning alert to note that a response to a System Error Group could not be retrieved due to a communication timeout. If this happens repeatedly, please check your network and/or contact support.microsoft.com with the error information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule is used internally by Operations Manager. Overrides to this rule will cause behavior that may not be what you expect.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule is used internally by Operations Manager. Overrides to this rule will cause behavior that may not be what you expect.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: While running as a part of the discovery wizard, the computer verification process failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated events and alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert contains information on the problem encountered. In case of a RPC error, make sure there are no firewall issues. In case of access issues, make sure the module is launched under right set of credentials that can do verification. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: While running as a part of the discovery wizard, the computer verification process failed with a generic error.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated events and alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert contains information on the problem encountered. In case of a RPC error, make sure there are no firewall issues. In case of access issues, make sure the module is launched under right set of credentials that can do verification. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.
For more information on troubleshooting agent installation, see Troubleshooting Issues When You Use the Discovery Wizard to Install an Agent(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181932).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events generated by Computer Verification module that can be used in either reporting or a view to diagnose issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Computer Verification module had failed to verify a few computers. As a result, if this module was running as part of a discovery, then discovery/agent deployment on these failed computers would not proceed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Events and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details, 'Computer Verification: Module Error' alerts, and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rolls up overall availability health for the Management Configuration service.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects when the Management Configuration service has problems connecting to the Operational Database that continually happen for some period of time. The default configuration of this monitor is listed in the Configuration Section.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to generate a critical state when the Management Configuration service could not completely verify connectivity to the database or receive any configuration change in the last 30 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This is usually caused by some problem with network connectivity or database integrity problem.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check connectivity from the Root Management Server to the Operational Database server. Note that you need to monitor the ongoing network connectivity since intermittent network problems may hide the problem.

If you are still getting a critical state and System Center Management Health Services in your Operations Manager infrastructure are not getting updated Management Packs or configuration, please contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with the name of this rule and information from the context of the state change event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health from Unit Monitors that detect when the Management Configuration service cannot connect to the Operational Database.
To troubleshoot this issue, navigate to one of the Unit Monitors to view its state change event and the knowledge on that monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects when the Management Configuration service has problems connecting to the Operational Database that continually happen for some period of time. The default configuration of this monitor is listed in the Configuration Section.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to generate a critical state when the Management Configuration service could not completely verify connectivity to the database or receive any configuration change in the last 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This is usually caused by some problem with network connectivity or database integrity problem.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check connectivity from the Root Management Server to the Operational Database server. Note that you need to monitor the ongoing network connectivity since intermittent network problems may hide the problem.

If you are still getting a critical state and System Center Management Health Services in your Operations Manager infrastructure are not getting updated Management Packs or configuration, please contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with the name of this rule and information from the context of the state change event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health from various monitors that detect non-healthy conditions of the Management Configuration service accessing the Operational Database.
Navigate through the Health Explorer Unit Monitors that have the warning or critical state to see the state change information and specific knowledge to help troubleshoot problems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if there are problems with the Management Configuration service reading from the Operational Database. It indicates that the Management Configuration service does have access to the Operational Database, but is unable to calculate which objects need updated configuration because there is too much churn updates/deletes of objects due to a flood of discovery data.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to detect if the database has not stabilized in the last 30 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may happen if there is a flood of discovery data coming from all the System Center Management Health Services at once and the database is still busy being updated on what objects have been discovered by each System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the database server health to ensure that it is under optimal performance conditions. If the database server is suffering from degraded performance or is not sized appropriately, this could be the cause for the Management Configuration service not being able to calculate which objects need updated configuration because each of the Collection Management Servers are constantly inserting discovery data.

Another problem could be that the System Center Management Health Services are simply inserting too much discovery data. If this is the first time these objects are being discovered, this may be normal until everything has been discovered.

If this happening even after the initial deployment of agents and/or new Management Packs, contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with the name of this rule and the information from the state change event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health that detects if there are problems with the Management Configuration service reading from the Operational Database. Check the individual Unit Monitors to view their state change event, context, and knowledge on how to troubleshoot this problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if there are problems with the Management Configuration service reading from the Operational Database. It indicates that the Management Configuration service does have access to the Operational Database, but is unable to calculate which objects need updated configuration because there is too much churn updates/deletes of objects due to a flood of discovery data.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to detect if the database has not stabilized in the last 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may happen if there is a flood of discovery data coming from all the System Center Management Health Services at once and the database is still busy being updated on what objects have been discovered by each System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the database server health to ensure that it is under optimal performance conditions. If the database server is suffering from degraded performance or is not sized appropriately, this could be the cause for the Management Configuration service not being able to calculate which objects need updated configuration because each of the Collection Management Servers are constantly inserting discovery data.

Another problem could be that the System Center Management Health Services are simply inserting too much discovery data. If this is the first time these objects are being discovered, this may be normal until everything has been discovered.

If this happening even after the initial deployment of agents and/or new management packs, contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with the name of this rule and the information from the state change event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if the Management Configuration service is unable to respond to requests from System Center Management Health Services for new configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to generate a critical state when the Management Configuration service is unable to response to configuration requests in 120 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This be can caused when the servers and services comprising the Operations Manager Management Group Infrastructure are not sized correctly and system cannot scale to the needs of all the agents.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you are within supported configuration for the number of agents and objects that need to be monitored, contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with this monitor name and the state change event information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health that detects if there are problems with the Management Configuration service core engine. Check the individual Unit Monitors to view their state change event, context, and knowledge on how to troubleshoot this problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if the Management Configuration service is unable to respond to requests from System Center Management Health Services for new configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The default configuration is to generate a critical state when the Management Configuration service is unable to response to configuration requests in 60 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This be can caused when the servers and services comprising the Operations Manager Management Group Infrastructure are not sized correctly and system cannot scale to the needs of all the agents.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you are within supported configuration for the number of agents and objects that need to be monitored, contact Customer Support Services (CSS) with this monitor name and the state change event information.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Management Configuration service is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When the Management Configuration service is not running, no new configuration will be set to any of the System Center Management Health Services. Check the Operations Manager and System event logs to determine why the Management Configuration service has entered a stopped state.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Restart the System Center Management Configuration service on the Root Management Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Consecutive Samples Module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated event.
The cause of the failure could be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
The specified computer could not be reached. The associated event description contains the specific error.
Insufficient credentials for operation. The associated event description has more information.
The specified performance counter information was invalid. The associated event description contains the specific error code.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.
This could be either:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Correct the erroneous configuration element from the error event.
Provide correct credentials or fix network issues that might prevent the remote computer from being accessed.
Verify whether the counter information is correct, and whether it can be sampled using Performance Monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to consolidate data. The rule or monitor trying to do the consolidation was unloaded by the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A rule or monitor that tried to consolidate data failed. This is usually due to a misconfigured rule or monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated alert context. Look for the name of the rule or monitor (workflow name) and ensure that the rule or monitor is properly configured.
The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with consolidation:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Consolidator module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Consolidator module:
