maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Correlation module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Number of configured input ports does not match the expected value of 2.
Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Item policy value was not recognized, the module configuration schema does not match the implementation.
The correlation policy of reset window can not be used with an "any order" correlation order setting.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Correlation module:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Delta Threshold Module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated event.
The cause of the failure could be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
The specified computer could not be reached. The associated event description contains the specific error.
Insufficient credentials for operation. The associated event description has more information.
The specified performance counter information was invalid. The associated event description contains the specific error code.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.
This could be either:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Correct the erroneous configuration element from the error event.
Provide correct credentials or fix network issues that might prevent the remote computer from being accessed.
Verify whether the counter information is correct, and whether it can be sampled using Performance Monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to check the state of a service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A rule or monitor tried to check the state of a service but failed to do so. This could be due to a number of reasons

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service does not exist on the computer
The Agent action account does not have permissions to check the service
The rule or monitor is misconfigured

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated alert context.
Check the rule or monitor name, also check the detailed information about what the error was.
Ensure that the service exists on the computer.
Ensure that the agent action account has permissions on the computer
Check the rule or monitor (workflow name) to ensure that it is properly configured.
The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with service related events:

A runtime error occurred during initialization. Check the event for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Dependent Service Check Probe module:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that an Operations Manager agent attempted to discover or generate data about an object that resides on another computer. This is not allowed by default, but is sometimes required for proper monitoring. For example, the agent might be running as part of a cluster, and trying to discover the virtual cluster node.
The agent will not be able to do this until agent proxy is enabled.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: It may be completely valid for the agent to discover objects residing on another computer. You must review the details of the alert description to determine if the agent should be configured with proxying.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you have reviewed that the agent should be able to discover and send data on behalf of another computer, you should enable proxying for that agent:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Go to the Administration space in the Operations Manager Console
Find the agent in the Agent Managed view
Open Properties for that agent
In the Security tab, check the Allow this agent to act as a proxy option
Click OK

maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Expression Filter module:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects all failed file transfers as the source file could not be processed by the file upload module.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor monitors the file upload quotas i.e. the number of pending files that are in process of being transferred over to the management server by a monitored agent. If it exceeds the configured quota, an alert will be raised upon two consecutive failed attempts to transfer a file to the management server. The alert will auto resolve if the file processing falls back within the quota specified denoted by a missed failed attempt.
The following summarizes the default thresholds:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Maximum Pending files (Default value 512)
Maximum pending file bytes (Default size 10GB)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A brief summary of potential causes are:

maml:listItem.maml:para: A malicious agent may be trying to cause the server to run out of disk space by uploading too much data. All the above mentioned limits apply to both file uploads that have not yet completed as well as completed uploads which have not been posted (and acknowledged) by a data source instance yet.
A failed/missing rule for completing file uploads.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The manual resolution steps that can be performed are:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Investigate the malicious agent for uploading data over quota limit.
Use the task for listing failed rules/monitors on the management server to check and see if any rules processing completed file uploads have failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: While calculating group membership, an exception occurred and the calculation could not complete. This rule is disabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unexpected condition occurred. This could be due to an issue with the implementation of group discovery, a transient issue, or a high load on the all management servers resource pool.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Refer to the information provided in the event details for guidance in resolving the specific issue that has occurred.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor indicates that the target System Center Management Health Service that this Watcher is monitoring does not have a properly configured default action account.
This will affect the target Health Service ability to run rules and monitors.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: While downloading updated action account configuration, this may have been corrupted in transit.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can follow the below steps to initiate an agent repair which will force the agent to update it management pack and configuration cache as part of the repair process:

maml:entry.maml:para: Click the Agent Managed view under Device Management
In the result pane, select one or more agents
Click Repair... in the Actions pane
You can use the default action account or supply alternate credentials

maml:section.maml:para: This should repair the agent and force it to request its new configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rolls up overall availability health for the Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor measures the Health Service Management Groups\Send Queue % Used and generates the following states:

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by a low bandwidth or high latency connection from this System Center Management Health Service to its parent Management Server. This can also be caused by rules that are collecting more data than the parent Management Server can process; especially when the parent Management Server has many agents reporting to it sending large amounts of data.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check with your network administrators if the network connection from the System Center Management Health Service to the parent Management Servers is saturated. If so, you may need to upgrade your networks to accommodate the traffic.

If you cannot upgrade your network (e.g. if your System Center Management Health Service or Gateway Server is at a remote branch office), you can disable unnecessary collection rules. Below are a list of rule types you can disable and their impact of disabling them:

maml:entry.maml:para: Collects performance data to either the Operational Database, Data Warehouse, or both

When a performance collection rule is disabled, any view that shows that performance data will no longer have data viewable. If the rule was collecting data to the Data Warehouse, reports dependent on that performance will no longer render any data.
Collects event data for diagnosis. In some cases, an event may not be helpful to alert on, but is helpful for either forensic troubleshooting or near real time troubleshooting.

When an event collection rule is disabled, any view that shows that event data will no longer have data viewable. If the rule was collecting data to the Data Warehouse, reports dependent on that event will no longer render any data.

maml:section.maml:para: Lastly, if you still need that data, one other option you can implement in the system to attempt to reduce the amount of data sent over the network is to use optimized performance counter collection rules and event consolidation collection rules. The below table summarizes their benefit and explains how the data is summarized.

maml:entry.maml:para: Only sends the performance data sample if it deviates from the last sample within some percentage. E.g., if the last sample was 42, and the rule was configured to only collect to a new sample with a tolerance of 10%, the next sample will need to 42 +/- 4.2 (e.g. next sample needs to be greater than 46.2 or less than 37.8)

Because only performance data that exceeds the configured tolerance is sent to the Operational Database or Data Warehouse, the data will be less precise. The larger your tolerance, the less the precision.

This type of event collection rule sends the data if one of the parameters it is configured with differs from the last event. E.g., you can configure a consolidated collection rule to consolidate events where the following are identical:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Event Source
Event ID
Source Computer
Description

maml:entry.maml:para: You can then configure a timeframe to consolidate these events (e.g. 10 minutes). If the above criteria match for any event, within that 10 minute window, only 1 event is sent up with its Repeat Count property incremented. If this event was occurring frequently on a single agent, this means there would only be 144 events sent up in a 24 hour period, which may be significantly less than the number of events actually logged to the event log

You need to be aware of which event parameters and properties you consolidate on. Configuring for example on the Description will mean that if the Event Description is typically unique (e.g. it contains a username) then you will still get many events sent up. For that example, you would instead want to consolidate over the Event Parameter that represents the username field.
Also, having a very large consolidation windows has to affects:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Delayed events viewable in the Event View or Reports (since the data needs to be consolidated until the end of that consolidation window)

Slightly higher resource utilization on the agent. With a low number of consolidation rules, this may be negligible. With a large number of these rules types compounded with long consolidation windows, the resource utilization will increase correspondingly.

maml:section.maml:para: See the product help or navigate to the Authoring space in the console to create the type of rules mentioned above.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The certificate used for authentication is about to expire. This certificate is used for certificate-based authentication from this System Center Management Health Service to other System Center Management Health Services.
This is the same certificate that was imported using the MOMCertImport.exe utility.
Once the certificate expires, the agent or management server will not be able to communicate with or report data to the management group.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The certificate is about to expire. After it has expired, the System Center Management Health Service will be unable to authenticate to other System Center Management Health Services.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Obtain a new certificate and import it using the MOMCertImport.exe utility.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on importing and using certificates in Operations Manager, see Managing Certificates in Operations Manager (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=824998).

For information about using the CertGenWizard.exe, an unsupported tool for requesting multiple certificates, see the blog post Obtaining Certificates for Non-Domain Joined Agents Made Easy With Certificate Generation Wizard (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195439).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor will generate a critical state on Heartbeat failure if the computer cannot be reached through an ICMP ping.
This is an indication that the target System Center Management Health Service on that computer has lost network connectivity to its parent Management Server.
Note that you will see 2 alerts when the computer is offline:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An alert for heartbeat failure (Health Service Heartbeat Failure)
An alert for the computer that is not responding to ICMP ping (Failed to connect to Computer)

maml:section.maml:para: When the computer network connectivity is restored and the System Center Management Health Service starts to heartbeat, then both alerts will be automatically closed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The computer is not plugged/connected to the network
The network infrastructure (e.g. routers/switches) supporting communication between the target System Center Management Health Service and its parent Management Server are experiencing problems.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can try the following to diagnose and remediate this issue:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Perform a trace route to check if there is packet loss to a router or switch to the target System Center Management Health Service. You can use the tracert.exe utility in Windows. If you have Window XP or Windows Server 2003 and higher, you can use pathping.exe
Physically check the target computer to ensure it is connected or plugged into the network
Check with your network administrators if there are any known issues or outages that may be affecting the target System Center Management Health Service and its parent Management Server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor indicates that the target System Center Management Health Service that this Watcher is monitoring was not able to parse and load recently received configuration.
This will affect the target System Center Management Health Service ability to run rules and monitors.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: While downloading updated configuration, this may have been corrupted in transit. Another reason could be the fact that MSXML6 is missing.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: One resolution is to enable recoveries to automatically repair the agent.

In the event that the recovery is disabled or was not successful, you can follow the below steps to initiate an agent repair which will force the agent to update its management pack and configuration cache as part of the repair process. It also reinstalls (if needed) all technologies required.

maml:entry.maml:para: Click the Agent Managed view under Device Management
In the result pane, select one or more agents
Click Repair... in the Actions pane
You can use the default action account or supply alternate credentials

maml:section.maml:para: This should repair the agent and force it to request its new configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view. This rule is disabled by default as it can result in excessive event collections, which create overhead for the management group and consume space in the operational and data warehouse databases. If enabled, it is recommended that that the rule only be enabled for a limited period of time.
Instead of enabling this rule, perform the following steps.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open "Operations Manager" Log in Event Viewer under "Applications and Services Logs".
Right click "Operations Manager" and select "Filter Current Log".
In the "Filter Current Log" window, under "Event Sources" dropdown, check "HealthService" and "OpsMgr Connector" and uncheck the rest.
In the "Filter Current Log" window, enter "21024,21025,1210" in the Event IDs.
Press OK to view the necessary events.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor indicates that this System Center Management Health Service has failed to load configuration successfully.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may be caused by issues in the configuration file.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Please view the parent roll-up monitor for the steps to troubleshoot this issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor indicates that this System Center Management Health Service requires new configuration but has not received it for over 90 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may be caused by network connectivity issues to the Management Server this System Center Management Health Service reports to. There are additional causes listed in the parent roll-up monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Please view the parent roll-up monitor for the steps to troubleshoot this issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor detects if a System Center Management Health Service has failed to process a configuration or its configuration is out-of-date. System Center Management Health Service configuration includes the management packs that apply to the System Center Management Health Service and the Run As accounts that the System Center Management Health Service needs to use.

This aggregate monitor will roll up the state of the child unit monitors. The unit monitors that roll up to this aggregate monitor are disabled by default; review and enable the unit monitors as needed for your monitoring requirements.
View the product knowledge for each unit monitor to identify the criteria for critical and warning states.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may be caused by a communication outage to the parent management server for this System Center Management Health Service.

If this System Center Management Health Service is communicating with a gateway server rather than a management server, it may take more time for the System Center Management Health Service to get the up-to-date configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The following steps should be followed to diagnose and resolve this issue:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check that the System Center Management service and System Center Management Configuration service are both started on the collection management servers. If either service is not started, the new configuration cannot be propagated to the rest of the System Center Management Health Services. Start the collection management servers' System Center Management service and System Center Management Configuration service, if not running.

Check if this System Center Management Health Service is reporting up through a gateway server. If it is reporting through a gateway server, verify that the System Center Management service is running on that server and any management servers the gateway server connects to.

If the services are all running, attempt to restart the System Center Management Health Service on this agent. System Center Management Health Service restart will attempt to get the most recent configuration.

If this does not address the issue, you can follow the below steps to initiate an agent repair which will force the agent to update its management pack and configuration cache as part of the repair process:

maml:entry.maml:para: Click the Agent Managed view under Device Management
In the result pane, select one or more agents
Click Repair in the Actions pane
You can use the default action account or supply alternate credentials

maml:section.maml:para: This should repair the agent and force it to request its new configuration.

The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This unit monitor indicates that this System Center Management Health Service requires new configuration but has not received it for over 45 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This may be caused by network connectivity issues to the Management Server this System Center Management Health Service reports to. There are additional causes listed in the parent roll-up monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Please view the parent roll-up monitor for the steps to troubleshoot this issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service Connector was unable to listen on TCP port.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This is typically caused by another application already listening on required TCP port.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Investigate application already subscribed to TCP port could be stopped which will allow System Center Operations Manager to use that port.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that the secure reference override was not resolved in requested context. Workflows are not loaded until this problem is fixed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Secure reference override was requesting to use of credentials which are not delivered to System Center Management Health Service yet and are not present in secure storage DB.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Credentials need to be approved for delivery manually. This approval causes override resolution to succeed and all workflows using modules running as override profile to load and execute.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates that a Run As Account specified in a Run As Profile cannot be resolved. Workflows that use the Profile will be not loaded until this problem is fixed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This condition may have occurred because the Account is not configured to be distributed to the specified computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To resolve this problem, you need to open the Run As Profile specified below, locate the Account entry as specified by its SSID, and either choose to distribute the Account to this computer if appropriate, or change the setting in the Profile so that the target object does not use the specified Account. Note: you may use the command shell to get the Run As Account display name by its SSID.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events about failures that occur when a rule or monitor attempts to generate an alert and one or more parameter replacement actions fail. If these events are being generated then there is a problem with the way the rule or monitor has been authored. Since these events are also being monitored by alert generating rules, this rule is disabled by default to reduce on the data collected. This rule can be enabled for investigation purposes but should otherwise be disabled. Events collected by this rule will show in the "Health Manager Events" view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule runs a response that periodically performance maintenance on the System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This section is not applicable for this rule.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: There is no resolution to perform for this rule since it does not generate state or alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service has stopped on a computer.

This alert is generated by a Heath Service Watcher. This object is run on the All Management Servers Resource Pool and monitors the health of all System Center Management Health Services in a Management Group. When a System Center Management Health Service fails to heartbeat, as set of Diagnostics are run and Recoveries are then executed to attempt to fix this problem with the remote agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service has been stopped.
The System Center Management Health Service failed to start up correctly.
The System Center Management Health Service has been set to Manual/Disabled and the machine was rebooted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Recoveries may be enabled to restart the agent.

In the event that the recovery is disabled or was not successful, you can navigate to the "State Change Events" tab and run the recovery from the details pane. To open the State Change Events tab, right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, select the alert that is in a critical state, and then in the right-hand pane, click the State Change Events tab. In the details pane, click the recovery task.

Note: A diagnostic task for this monitor runs ping. The default firewall settings for computers running Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008 prevent the computers from providing a ping response. To configure these computers to allow incoming ICMP traffic, see "Create an Inbound ICMP Rule on Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=161045).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The certificate for a computer that is attempting to communicate with Operations Manager is not trusted. The remote computer will not be monitored until the problem with the certificate is resolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The certificate for the remote computer is issued by a certificate authority that is not trusted by the server running Operations Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the details for the alert to identify the computer that is using an untrusted certificate. Configure the source computer to use a trusted certificate or configure the server running Operations Manager to trust the certificate authority that issued the certificate. For information about configuring certificates refer to the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Managing Certificates in Operations Manager (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=824998).
Managing Certificates from the Windows Server topics on TechNet (http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc771377.aspx).

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For additional information on certificates and security, see PKI Technologies (http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc779826(WS.10).aspx).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service is unable to obtain subject or issuer name from remote certificate.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The connector was unable to obtain subject or issuer name from remote certificate. See the event details for the algorithm used to obtain the name.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Confirm that the certificate is valid. Issue a new certificate using MOMCertImport. For information about obtaining and importing a certificate in Operations Manager 2012, see Managing Certificates in Operations Manager (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=227146).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule calculates the total CPU utilization of the Operations Manager agent and its related processes and then submits that as performance data under object “Health Service” and counter “agent processor utilization”.

This rule’s underlying script works by locating and sampling the CPU utilization for the Operations Manager agent process (HealthService.exe), its child monitoring host process (MonitoringHost.exe) and the child processes of those monitoring host processes (cscript.exe, PowerShell.exe, etc.). The script runs the calculation three times and writes the average of the three consecutive samples to the operations database and data warehouse.
See the Agent Performance view to review the data that has been sampled for the agents’ CPU utilization.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This data source generates the "agent processor utilization" counter for use in rules and monitors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor type is used for creating monitors which watch the agent processor utilization.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This probe is used to generate the "agent processor utilization" counter for use in rules and monitors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor calculates the total CPU utilization of the Operations Manager agent and its related processes, and generates an alert when CPU utilization exceeds a specified threshold for a specified number of consecutive samples.

The monitor’s underlying script works by locating and sampling the CPU utilization for the Operations Manager agent process (HealthService.exe), its child monitoring host process (MonitoringHost.exe) and the child processes of those monitoring host processes (cscript.exe, PowerShell.exe, etc.). The script runs the calculation three times and outputs the average of the three consecutive samples, which is then used by this monitor to determine critical or healthy state.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: You can use overrides to customize the following parameters to alter the default behavior of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Frequency (seconds). This is the frequency at which the monitor samples agent processor utilization. By default, the monitor evaluates the agent processor utilization every 300 seconds (5 minutes).
Number of consecutive samples for critical state. By default, this monitor reports a critical state when 6 consecutive samples exceed the specified threshold.
Number of consecutive samples for healthy state. By default, this monitor returns a healthy state when 3 consecutive samples are under the specified threshold.
Threshold. By default, the threshold for CPU utilization is 25%.

maml:section.maml:para: This monitor is disabled by default for all management servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Excessive CPU utilization of the various Operations Manager agent processes may indicate that agent or one of its underlying dependencies is not operating properly. If the agent and its underlying dependencies are updated properly, then the agent is being over-utilized on the system being monitored. This may be short-lived, due to a recent update in the management group, such as the deployment of a new management pack, or this may be due to the agent truly being under excessive load, in which case tuning may be required.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To ensure that the agent and its underlying dependencies are operating properly, check the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Verify that the most recent version of the Operations Manager agent is installed on the system.
Verify that the update for MSXML 6.0 provided in Knowledge Base article 968967 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181885) is installed.

If the system's operating system is Windows XP, Windows 2000 Server or Windows Server 2003, ensure that the system is running Windows Script Host 5.7 or later. The following link provides the download locations for Windows Script Host 5.7 http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181884.

maml:section.maml:para: If the condition persists after those configurations are verified, then deeper investigation is required to understand what is driving CPU utilization. Investigate further using any combination of the following steps:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Review the recent history of agent processor utilization, workflow count, and module counts using the following view: Agent Performance View. The agent processor utilization data will give insight into whether the issue is recent or has been occurring for a longer period of time. The workflow and module count data will give an indication of the workload that the various rules, monitors, and discoveries are putting on the agent. This data should also be compared against healthy agents to use as a contrast.

Use a tool such as the Effective Configuration Viewer (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=182300) to understand the number of class instances discovered on the agent. More class instances can lead to higher workflow and module counts, which can result in more workload.

Using Performance Monitor, collect more detailed % Processor Time measurements from the Process object. This will give insight as to which processes are contributing the most significantly to overall processor utilization.
Review any recent management pack updates or changes to see if they correspond with the increase in CPU utilization.

maml:section.maml:para: When the cause or causes are identified, any one of the following steps may be taken to address the issue:

maml:listItem.maml:para: If a management pack change was made recently or a new management pack was deployed, monitor the situation to see if the problem continues.
Reduce the frequency of discoveries via overrides to spread out their CPU utilization across the day. Doing this comes at the trade-off of discovery potentially taking longer to occur.
Reduce the frequency of rules or monitors that are run on a schedule to spread their CPU utilization across the day. Doing this comes at the trade-off of monitoring.

If the agent is managed by multiple management groups (a configuration referred to as “multi-homed”), that will contribute to higher processor utilization as well. Consider reducing the number of management groups that the agent is managed by.

maml:section.maml:para: If all of the steps above do not produce a solution, contact Microsoft Customer Service and Support (http://support.microsoft.com/).

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor has a related diagnostic task, “Collect agent processor utilization diagnostic”, which reruns the sampling of CPU utilization. The diagnostic task is disabled by default.

There is also a task in the Operations console, ”Get the agent processor utilization”, which reruns the sampling of CPU utilization. When you run the ”Get the agent processor utilization” task, you can set the time-out and number of samples parameters. The task returns a table of results. Run the Get the 'agent processor utilization' task

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Agent processor utilization calculator script.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service received a malformed data item. There is no user action that can be taken for this problem, so this monitor is disabled by default. Issues that can cause this problem are typically transient. If the problem occurs multiple times, uninstall and then reinstall the agent. If that does not resolve the problem, contact Microsoft Customer Service and Support.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Data is being rejected because agent proxying is not enabled for the agent that is trying to perform the action.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Agent proxying is not enabled for the agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Enable agent proxying or use overrides to disable the relevant discoveries for that agent. To enable agent proxy:

maml:listItem.maml:para: In the Operations console, click Administration.
Find the computer in the Agent Managed view
Open the Properties for that agent
On the Security tab, check the Allow this agent to act as a proxy option
Click OK

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor aggregates state from unit monitors that measure memory utilization of the System Center Management Health Service. When this monitor changes to critical, it starts a recovery task that restarts the System Center Management Health Service.

The hotfix provided in Knowledge Base article 968760 can correct some issues that result in this monitor changing to a critical state. Ensure that the hotfix from Knowledge Base article 968760 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=196234) has been installed on any computers that are using too much memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This roll-up monitor does not have alerting enabled, by default. If you want to be notified by an alert when this monitor changes to a critical state, you can use an override to enable alerting.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:para: This monitor indicates that the target System Center Management Health Service that this Watcher is monitoring was not able to load internal system rules.
This will affect the target System Center Management Health Service ability to run rules and monitors.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: While downloading updated configuration, this may have been corrupted in transit.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can follow the below steps to initiate an agent repair which will force the agent to update it management pack and configuration cache as part of the repair process:

maml:entry.maml:para: Click the Agent Managed view under Device Management
In the result pane, select one or more agents
Click Repair... in the Actions pane
You can use the default action account or supply alternate credentials

maml:section.maml:para: This should repair the agent and force it to request its new configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert/monitor state indicates that there were many corrupt and unreadable events in the event log that was being monitored.

The System Center Management Health Service attempted to read an event and a number of subsequent events in the event log were not readable. The default configuration of this monitor generates a warning state and alert when it encounters 21 consecutive events that the System Center Management Health Service was not able to process within 5 minutes.

If the System Center Management Health Service was able to process an event during or after that time, the monitor will transition to a healthy state and the original warning alert will be resolved automatically.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be cause by numerous issues including:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Corrupt event log
Application logging bad events

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can use the following steps to determine if there is a problem with event log that was being processed:
1. Take note of the rule or monitor name from the alert or monitor context. This is the text after Workflow name in the context.
2. Look up this name in the console and bring up the properties for that rule or monitor.
3. In the monitor or rule properties, look at the tabs that begin with Event Log (for example, "Event Log (Unhealthy Event))".

4. After taking note of the event log where this monitor or rule is configured to monitor, look for a related tab named Event Expression (for example, "Simple Event Expression" or "Repeated Event Expression").
5. Take note of the criteria here. You will use these criteria to filter the target computers event log to search for the corrupted event.
6. Once you have the event log and the expression (for example, Event ID equals 14384 AND Event Source equals Health Service) open the event viewer where this event originated from.
7. Click the event log identified in Step 3.

8. Filter the event log to look for the same event that the rule or monitor was configured to in Step 5. You can do this in the event viewer by right clicking on the event log name and choosing the View context menu option, then Filter From here you can filter by "Event Source" and "Event ID" similar to the expression from Step 5.
9. If any events show up in your view, open them in event viewer.
a. If you can successfully open the event, save the event log (Action menu, Save Log File As).
b. Contact customer support service and provide the monitor name and its current state, the steps you attempted to follow in the knowledge and the event log that you have saved for offline analysis.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor indicates that the Operations Manager agent unable to successfully access and open an event log to process its events. When Operations Manager is unable to access an event log, there may be degradation in monitoring events out of that event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The action account does not have the appropriate permissions to the event log indicated in the alert and monitor context.
The event log specified in the monitor or rule configuration does not exist on the computer where the monitor or rule is run.
The event log name may not be correct in the monitor or rule configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Refer to most recent error details in the alert description for the name of the event log.
1. Check that the action account for the Agent has the appropriate rights on the target computer to read from that event log.
2. Check that the event log exists on the computer on which this alert was raised.
3. Check the configuration in the rule or monitor, such as a misspelled name.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor and alert indicates that the System Center Management Health Service has been processing older events for a particular event log longer than expected.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if Operations Manager is still processing backlogged events after 10 minutes. This means that Operations Manager processed Event 25017 (started processing backlogged events), but has not reached the current record (indicated by event 25018).

Critical state: Transition from warning state to critical state if after 20 minutes, Operations Manager is still processing backlogged events. This means in addition to the 10 minutes that the System Center Management Health Service has already been processing backlogged events, an additional 10 minutes has passed, for a total of 20 minutes since Event 25017 has passed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Both the warning and critical state can indicate the following may be happening on the agent:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The computer where this event was raised is logging hundreds to thousands of events per minute that all need to be processed for monitoring.
The computer may be low on available resources (for example; memory).
The System Center Management Health Service was stopped for an extended period of time and must process all events from the last one it successfully processed.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can perform the following checks to further determine the root cause of the problem:
1. Open the event viewer on the computer where for this alert or monitor state.
2. Check to see if there is an application or event source that seems to be logging many events per minute to the event log

3. If there is no clear indication of the application that may be logging these events, check the resource utilization on this computer. If there is an application that is consuming large amounts of memory or CPU, check with the application owner or administrator if this is expected behavior.
4. If you are not concerned with the loss of monitoring from the existing events, you can clear the event log.
Note: Clearing the event log when the System Center Management Health Service is still processing backlogged events will result in loss of monitoring.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rolls up overall health for the Event Log module.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: There was an error returned from the Event Log API. The rule or monitor is unable to read from the specified event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: There may be a problem with the event log service on the target computer where this rule or monitor is running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Look through the Application and System Event Log on the specified computer. Look for any errors related to the Event Log service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor indicates that the System Center Management Health Service cannot verify whether the specified Run As account is valid.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the System Center Management Health Service cannot verify the validity of a Run As account (event 7015 or 7016)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service successfully validated all Run As accounts (7019)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service cannot verify the future validity of the specified Run As account due to:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An error retrieving information from Active Directory (for domain accounts)
Or, an error retrieving information from the local security authority (for local accounts)
Or, the account does not exist
Or, the account is disabled,
Or, the computer hosting the agent cannot access the domain the account is in
Or, the error specified in the event

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can perform the following steps to resolve the problem or to gather data prior to seeking assistance from Microsoft product support:

maml:listItem.maml:para: In the Operations Manager event log, filter for events 7015 and 7016 and get the list of accounts for which verification failed. For each account, ensure that the accounts associated with the Run As account specified in the events exist (in Active Directory for domain accounts or on the local computer for local accounts) and that the account is enabled.
Ensure that the computer hosting the agent can communicate with the domain, if the account is a domain account.
Review the error messages provided in the events and search for more details or contact Microsoft Customer Service and Support.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more Windows credentials being used in a Run As account have been blocked on this computer.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the System Center Management Health Service blocked access to the specified Windows credential (event 7017)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service has authorized all configured Run As accounts to execute (event 7025)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: By default, all credentials are permitted to run on a computer. This failure will occur if one or more credentials have been denied access on the computer with the HSLockdown tool.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The monitor will not return to a healthy state until all credential authorization issues are resolved on this computer. A 7025 event will be generated when all issues have been resolved.
You can perform the following steps to resolve the problem:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Identify the credentials that are trying to load but have been denied access to the computer. Look for 7017 events on the computer in question.
If the credentials should be permitted, run HSLockdown.exe with the "/A" parameter to add the credentials.

If the credentials should not be permitted, determine which Run As profiles are using these credentials and remove these credentials from those profiles. Update the profiles with permitted credentials.
If the workflows should not be running on this computer, use overrides to disable the workflows.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The account or password associated with the specified Run As account is expiring. If the account or password expires, the System Center Management Health Service will not be able to monitor or perform actions using this Run As account.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Critical state: Transition to critical state if the specified Run As account (event 7014) or its password (event 7001) will expire in less than 3 days
Warning state: Transition to warning state if the specified Run As account (event 7014) or its password (event 7001) will expire soon (in 4 days or more)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service has successfully validated all Run As accounts (except the unauthorized ones) (event 7019 or 7020)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The critical (or warning) state can indicate the following may be happening on the agent:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The account associated with the specified Run As account is expiring. If the account expiration is not extended before expiry, the System Center Management Health Service will not be able to monitor or perform actions using this Run As account.

The password associated with the specified Run As account is expiring. If the password is not updated before the expiry date, the System Center Management Health Service will not be able to monitor or perform actions using this Run As account.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Extend the account (update the account password) in Active Directory (for domain accounts) or on the local computer (for local accounts).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service could not log on with the specified Run As account because it has not been granted the requested logon right.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the specified Run As account has not been granted requested logon right on the managed computer (event 7002)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if all Run As accounts has been granted the requested logon right (event 7028)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service could not log on with the specified Run As account because it has not been granted the requested logon right.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Grant the requested logon right to the specified Run As Account using either Group Policy or Local Computer Policy (under Computer Configuration -> Security Settings -> User Rights Assignment).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Rolls up overall availability health for the secure storage manager and Run As Account infrastructure.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service could not log on the specified Run As account. This will prevent the System Center Management Health Service from monitoring or performing actions using this Run As account
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the System Center Management Health Service could not log on the specified Run As account (event 7000)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service successfully logged on all Run As accounts (7024)

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service could not log on the specified Run As account. This will prevent the System Center Management Health Service from monitoring or performing actions using this Run As account.

maml:listItem.maml:para: The password entered for the Run As account may be incorrect.
The account or its password may have expired.
The account may be disabled.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can perform the following steps to resolve the problem or to gather data prior to seeking assistance from Microsoft product support:
The password entered for the Run As account may be incorrect. Re-enter the password by

maml:entry.maml:para: Select the Run As Account node on the left pane
Find the specified Run As account and open its properties
Select the Account tab and re-enter the correct password

maml:listItem.maml:para: Extend the account (or update its password) in Active Directory (for domain accounts) or on the local computer (for local accounts)
Ensure that the account is enabled in Active Directory (for domain accounts) or on the local computer (for local accounts)

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Each System Center Management Health Service in the Management Group has a corresponding Heath Service Watcher. The Health Service Watcher object monitors, or watches, the state of the remote System Center Management Health Service from the perspective of the All Management Servers Resource Pool.

This dependency monitor rolls up the availability health of the System Center Management Health Service it is monitoring. This gives you a unified view of the health of a System Center Management Health Service:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Health Model of the System Center Management Health Service monitors itself locally on the target computer.
The Health Model of the Health Service Watcher monitors heartbeats from the System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Each System Center Management Health Service in the Management Group has a corresponding Heath Service Watcher. The Health Service Watcher object monitors, or watches, the state of the remote System Center Management Health Service from the perspective of the All Management Servers Resource Pool.

This dependency monitor rolls up the configuration health of the System Center Management Health Service it is monitoring. This gives you a unified view of the health of a System Center Management Health Service:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Health Model of the System Center Management Health Service monitors itself locally on the target computer.
The Health Model of the Health Service Watcher monitors heartbeats from the System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Each System Center Management Health Service in the Management Group has a corresponding Health Service Watcher. The Health Service Watcher object monitors, or watches, the state of the remote System Center Management Health Service from the perspective of the All Management Servers Resource Pool.

This dependency monitor rolls up the performance health of the System Center Management Health Service it is monitoring. This gives you a unified view of the health of a System Center Management Health Service:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Health Model of the System Center Management Health Service monitors itself locally on the target computer.
The Health Model of the Health Service Watcher monitors heartbeats from the System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Each System Center Management Health Service in the Management Group has a corresponding Health Service Watcher. The Health Service Watcher object monitors, or watches, the state of the remote System Center Management Health Service from the perspective of the All Management Servers Resource Pool.

This dependency monitor rolls up the security health of the System Center Management Health Service it is monitoring. This gives you a unified view of the health of a System Center Management Health Service:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The Health Model of the System Center Management Health Service monitors itself locally on the target computer.
The Health Model of the Health Service Watcher monitors heartbeats from the System Center Management Health Service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager attempted to run an executable and was unable to create the process.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The executable could not be found.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example: memory) to run the executable.
The antivirus software on the computer blocking Visual Basic scripts or Java scripts. The following link is a link to the KB article regarding this issue.
The script extension is not properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the path to the executable exists on the computer.
The antivirus software is not blocking scripts from running.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.
To ensure that all script extensions are registered, follow the steps in the “Let me fix it myself” section of Knowledge Base article 949140 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=181825).

maml:section.maml:para: Check the error information in the event or alert context for the script path and name. There could be a problem with the script not handling an error correctly and exiting. If the script exits without outputting the data that is expected (e.g. property bag data), this error is raised.
Another error can be caused by the misconfiguration of the rule or monitor executing this script. The configuration (script parameters, policy, timeout) could be wrong causing no output or timeout.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The IIS Discovery Probe module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
A runtime error occurred during initialization. Check the event for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.

maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the IIS Log Condition module:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Execution of the Learning Module failed. This rule generates an alert when any of the following event IDs is logged: 10118, 10119, 10120, 10121, 10122. These events occur when a read, write, or create operation fails for the following registry location:
HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Microsoft Operations Manager\3.0\Modules\Baselining\

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The registry operation may have failed for one of the following reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The action account doesn’t have the required permissions for these operations.

The action account used when the above registry location was initially created has the read/write permissions on this key. If the action account is changed after the installation, the new action account can’t access the registry because the new account is different than the one that initially created the registry key.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Try the following steps to resolve the issue:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Review the event log and find any of the above events to determine the issues that are causing the alert.
Ensure that the Action Account has read and write permissions to the registry location.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This alert indicates a problem with the authoring of the management pack.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: There is an error in the workflow that is trying to use the Learning Module.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The implementation of the workflow must be fixed in the management pack.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This dependency monitor rolls up the most critical state from all Management Servers to the Management Group.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Pivot to the individual state of each Management Server to determine the Management Server that is in a critical state.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up the Health Service Availability roll-up monitor from the Root Management Server up to the Management Group state.
Any critical state on the Root Management Servers affecting its Health Service state will be rolled up through this roll-up monitor.

Critical state on the Root Management Server should be addressed quickly as it will severely impact the health of the whole Management Group if the Root Management Server is not functioning correctly.

maml:section.maml:title: (Deprecated) Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Drill down into the Root Management Servers Health Model using the Health Explorer to troubleshoot the individual unit and aggregate monitors that are rolling up the critical state.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule is disabled by default because it has been replaced by a monitor.
This rule measures the Process\Handle Count utilization for all instances of the MonitoringHost.exe process. If it exceeds the configured threshold, an alert is generated.
There are different thresholds depending on the role that System Center Management Health Service configured to perform. The following summarizes the default thresholds:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:para: Below is the configuration for the response that attempts to restart the System Center Management Health Service:

maml:para.maml:ui: System Center Management Health Service Role

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A brief summary of potential causes are:

maml:entry.maml:para: Too many rules and monitors are loaded from all the management packs this System Center Management Health Service has been configured with.
A misconfigured rule or monitor collecting too much data or processing too much data (e.g. performance counter collection rule collecting data every 1 second)

maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by the System Center Management Health Service running many management packs. Each Management Pack may have a lot of monitoring that uses a small amount of resources. With many management packs that add up to many thousands of rules and monitors, each MonitoringHost.exe instance may start consuming more resources.
This may be expected for this System Center Management Health Service depending on the type of monitoring the System Center Management Health Service is performing.

Another cause could be one or more rules and monitors that are not conforming to some best practices. An example is a performance counter rule that attempts to collect performance data every 1 second. Too many rules or monitors configured this way will cause the monitoring host.exe process to consume more resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The default action for this rule running on Management Servers is to alert.
If you feel that the resource utilization is appropriate for the amount of monitoring being performed by this agent, you can override the threshold or disable the recovery.

If the System Center Management Health Service and its associated MonitoringHost.exe process are still consuming too many resources, you can restart the System Center Management Health Service windows service to mitigate this problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The default action for this rule running on Management Servers is to alert.
If you feel that the resource utilization is appropriate for the amount of monitoring being performed by this agent, you can override the threshold or disable the recovery.

If the System Center Management Health Service and its associated MonitoringHost.exe process are still consuming too many resources, you can restart the System Center Management Health Service windows service to mitigate this problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more attempts by a device, a connector, or an agent to authenticate to this management server failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The authentication failures could be due to one of the following causes:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The remote certificate was not trusted
A device is pending approval
The certificate is not imported correctly
The management server and the computer attempting to authenticate are configured to use different authentication settings

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: View the details for the alert to identify the event that triggered the alert.

For event 20072: View the details for the alert to identify the computer that is using an untrusted certificate. Configure the source computer to use a trusted certificate or configure the server running Operations Manager to trust the certificate authority that issued the certificate. For information about configuring certificates refer to the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Managing Certificates in Operations Manager (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=824998).
Managing Certificates from the Windows Server topics on TechNet (http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc771377.aspx).

maml:section.maml:para: For event 20002: Open the Administration area in the Operations console and click Pending Management. Select objects listed and click Approve or Reject, as appropriate.

For event 21003: Ensure the root certificate of the Certificate Authority that issued the certificate for the computer identified in the alert details is imported to Trusted Root Certification Authorities . For instructions on importing a Trusted Root certificate, see the topic for your type of certificate authority in Authentication and Data Encryption for Windows Computers (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=161162).
For event 21011: Check the authentication settings for both computers in Group Policy and Local Security Policy.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more rules or monitors are trying to access a log in the windows event log but they failed to do so. They will continue to attempt to access the log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Rules and Monitors may fail to access an event log for one of the following reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The event log is corrupt or not present on the system.
The rule or monitor has been configured with the incorrect name of the log.
The Operations Manager action account does not have access to the event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Look at the name of the event log provided in the alert context.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Use the computer management task to connect to the computer, and confirm that the event log is present and accessible.

Confirm that the name of the event log shown in the computer management snap-in is the same as what was shown in the alert. If that is not the case then update the workflow to use the correct name of the log.
More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event context. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Backward Compatibility Application Log module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
A runtime error occurred during initialization. Check the event for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Backward Compatibility Application Log module:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: View Backward Compatibility Application Log Events

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to run a WMI query.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Backward Compatibility WMI Event Mapper module encountered an unexpected runtime error.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Backward Compatibility WMI Event Mapper module:

maml:section.maml:para: The Backward Compatibility WMI Event Mapper module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the Backward Compatibility WMI Event Mapper module:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: View Backward Compatibility WMI Event Mapper Events

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to convert data in a rule or monitor into performance data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This is usually due to a misconfigured rule or monitor that Operations Manager tries to run. The rule or monitor tries to convert some data (for example from a script) into performance data.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event in the alert context and noting the rule or monitor that caused the error (the workflow name). Then reconfigure that rule or monitor.
The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with converting data into performance data:
