maml:section.maml:para: The MOM NT Performance Mapper module experienced an initialization failure and could not be loaded.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the MOM NT Performance Mapper module:

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: View MOM NT Performance Mapper Events

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A workflow such as a rule or monitor requires that its frequency be greater than zero.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The workflow indicated in the alert has been configured with a frequency of zero.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Review the alert details to identify the rule, monitor, or other workflow that generated the alert. Check the overrides for the workflow. If an override for frequency is configured as zero or the default configuration is set to zero, modify the the value to be greater than zero. For instructions on setting overrides, see How to use the Monitor Overrides (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=824988).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: OleDb Probe module encountered an error while building result set. As a result, the current output data item will contain failure information as opposed to result data.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated output data item, events and alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: OleDb Probe module encountered an error during execution. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Events and Alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the Alert contains information on the problem encountered. Please check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: OleDb Probe module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:
• Some value was out of the expected range. Check the event for more details.
• Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
• A runtime error occurred during initialization. Check the event for more details.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects events generated by OleDb Probe module that can be used in either reporting or a view to diagnose issues.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This section is not applicable to event collection rules.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: There is no resolution to perform for event collection rules since they do not generate state or alerts.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Monitor that checks for bad duplicate relationship records between agents and servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: One of the most common forms of corrupt data is when agents end up having more than one relationship to a given management server (either primary or secondary).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To fix this problem run the following task in the Operations console. Run the Fix duplicate relationships for agents to server in operational database task

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The processes that run to partition and groom the data stored in the operational database have not completed successfully in recent history. If these processes continue to not complete successfully then the performance of the operational database will be negatively impacted, which will slow down the entire management group. Ultimately the operational database will fill up entirely and the management group will cease to function.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor could be overridden to provide a different configuration:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Interval Seconds: Set the frequency to evaluate the state of the monitor
Maximum days since last success: Set the maximum number of days that can pass without partitioning and grooming completing successfully, before it is considered a problem.
Sample Count: Set the sample count before changing state and send an alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The reason this alert has been generated is because the partitioning and grooming process have not completed successfully within recent history. By default, this monitor is configured to generate an alert if the processes have not completed successfully within the previous 2 days. Some of the causes for the partitioning and grooming process not completing successfully include the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The "Partitioning and Grooming" rule is disabled
The "Partitioning and Grooming" rule is failing to access the SQL Server hosting the operational database in order to run the SQL stored procedures that perform grooming and partitioning.
The SQL stored procedures that perform partitioning and grooming are failing due to insufficient SQL log file space for the operational database.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The following steps cover how to troubleshoot and resolve this issue for the most common issues:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Ensure the "Partitioning and Grooming" rule does not have any overrides applied to it which would disable it.

The "Partitioning and Grooming" rule is run on the collection management server and runs under the credentials provided in the "Operational Database Account" Run As profile. If no credentials are provided in the "Operational Database Account" Run As profile, then the collection management server's default action account will be used. Confirm that the account being used to run the rule is configured with sufficient permissions. Refer to the help topic "How to Create a New Run As Account for Accessing the Operations Manager Database" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=824999) for more information.

The process of partitioning and grooming the operational database requires space in the SQL transaction log of the operational database. If there is not sufficient space in the transaction logs, then partitioning or grooming can fail. You can review the percent of space available in the transaction log with the "SQLServer:Databases\Percent Log Used" performance counter. Add more space to existing transaction log file(s), add more files or take the necessary steps to free up space within the existing log file(s) so that partitioning and grooming has enough space to complete. This is especially important if log shipping has been enabled on the operational database. Refer to the "Understanding and Managing Transaction Logs" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=193419) topic in the SQL books online for more information about transaction logs.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The operational database is running out of free space. Sufficient free space is needed to ensure that monitoring can continue uninterrupted. By default this monitor changes into a warning state of there is less than 40% available free space, and an error state if there is less than 20% available free space.
It is not recommended to change these thresholds, as 40% free space is generally required for a healthy operational database.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A large increase in the amount of data saved to the operational database can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: New agents added to the Management Group
New Management Packs imported
Changes to existing management pack rules or monitors
An operational condition in the environment that is causing more than the typical amount of data (e.g. more alerts)

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Increase the amount of free space by growing the database file. You can also change the grooming settings to store data for a shorter period of time.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This roll-up monitor rolls up health from each of the Operational Database Watchers that are members of this group.
The default configuration of this group is to roll-up the best state from all members to this group.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance counter data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Performance Data Source module encountered an error during initialization. As a result, the module will unload causing associated rules to unload as well.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to several reasons. Information about the failure is available in the associated Event.
The cause of the failure could be:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Some configuration value is invalid. The associated event description contains the specific value that was rejected.
The specified computer could not be reached. The associated event description contains the specific error.
Insufficient credentials for operation. The associated event description has more information.
The specified Performance Counter Information was invalid. The associated event description contains the specific error code.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Identify and correct the configuration causing a problem by examining the associated event description.
This could be either:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Correct the erroneous configuration element from the error event.
Provide correct credentials or fix network issues that might prevent the remote computer from being accessed.
Verify whether the counter information is correct, and whether it can be sampled using Performance Monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor pings the target computer on a regular interval and changes state based on whether a response is received or not. By default this monitor is only enabled for agentless managed computers. If the monitor is enabled for an agent-managed computer then the agent will ping itself. This monitor relies on the Win32_PingStatus method WMI to perform its pings and as such will only works on Windows XP and higher or Windows Server 2003 and higher.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: 1. The default firewall settings for computers running Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008 prevent the computers from providing a ping response. This cause applies to agent-managed and agentless managed systems alike.
2. If the computer is being agentlessly managed, the computer may no longer be responding via ICMP Ping. This can happen for the following reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The computer has been rebooted or shut down
The computer's network adapter is not plugged into the network
The ICMP Ping request is being dropped or the Time To Live (TTL) has expired

maml:section.maml:para: 3. If the computer is agent-managed, this could indicate a problem with the local network adapter.
4. There could also be a problem with WMI.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: For computers running Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008, configure the firewall to allow incoming ICMP traffic. For instructions, see "Create an Inbound ICMP Rule on Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=161045).
Check if the remote machine is plugged into the network and that it has an IP address. Locally log into the machine, and type the following at the command line:
ipconfig
If the computer doesn't have an IP address or the IP address is 0.0.0.0, repair the network connection on the local machine by following the steps below:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open the Control Panel
Open Network Connections

maml:section.maml:para: If the category view, Network Connections can be found in the Network and Internet Connections category.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Right click on the network connection that cannot be pinged, and choose Repair
Check again that the computer has a valid IP address by typing ipconfig from the command line.
If this does not work, disable the network connection and then enable it.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service could not run a PowerShell script as part of a rule or monitor due to over utilization.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Too many PowerShell scripts being run by the System Center Management Health Service.
PowerShell scripts are taking too long to execute.
PowerShell scripts are running too frequently.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example; memory) to run the PowerShell script.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. However, there may be other rules or monitors failing as well. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, consider reducing the frequency of the PowerShell script.
Ensure that the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.

maml:section.maml:para: This can also be caused when too many PowerShell scripts are being scheduled. This could be the result of an event storm or a misconfigured timer. In both cases the rule configuration will have to be examined to determine why the PowerShell script is running too often and usually will need to be backed down somehow (increasing the interval).

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service was attempting to run an PowerShell script and was unable to create the PowerShell run space.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Incorrectly configured PowerShell install.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example; memory) to create the PowerShell run space.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the PowerShell script:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That PowerShell is installed correctly on the computer.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.

maml:section.maml:para: Lastly, you should check verify the action account has sufficient access to run PowerShell.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service was attempting to run an PowerShell script and was unable to load a PowerShell Snap In.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Incorrectly registered Snap In.
Incorrectly configured Snap In.
Incorrectly configured PowerShell install.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the PowerShell script:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the Snap In name is spelled correctly in your workflow configuration.
That the Snap In and it's dependencies are correctly installed on the computer.
Lastly, you should check verify the action account has sufficient access to the SnapIn.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The PowerShell failed to execute successfully.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An incorrectly written script.
Incorrect configuration for the PowerShell Script (missing Data Item reference, incorrectly configured timeout).
Lack of permissions to access a resource used by script (Registry, File system, Service, etc...).
Resource (Registry, File system, Service, etc...) is slow, offline, or in a corrupted state.
The computer does not have enough resources (for example; memory) to run the executable.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the PowerShell script executes on the computer without error.
That the PowerShell script is configured correctly Data Item references are valid and present.
That the Action Account has access to the resources used by the PowerShell script.
That the computer is not over utilized.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Save the PowerShell script to a file and run it through PowerShell.exe.
Check Task Manager to see if there is enough free memory.
Check Task Manager to see if there are any processes consuming all the CPU.

maml:section.maml:para: Another error can be caused by the misconfiguration of the workflow executing this script. The configuration Snap Ins, Parameters, or Timeout Seconds could be incorrect.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The PowerShell failed to execute successfully because PowerShell is not properly installed.
This may affect some monitoring or discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: An incorrectly targeted rule running a PowerShell script.
PowerShell is not installed on the target machine.
PowerShell installation is corrupt.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The alert description and context has information indicating which rule or monitor failed. The following link will display all events indicating a failure to run the executable:
After reviewing the error in the context, check:
That the rule is correctly running on a machine where PowerShell should be installed.
That PowerShell is properly installed.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Attempt to run PowerShell.exe.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This aggregate monitor displays the overall health of the Collection Management Servers attempt to verify connectivity to the remote Management Server.
If this monitor is in a warning or critical state, expand the Monitor tree in the Health Explorer to find the specific unit monitor that is generating the warning or error state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The cause for this warning or error is calculated by the unit monitor.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The state of this monitor is based on the states of its unit monitors. To determine why the state of this monitor has changed, identify the unit monitor that changed its state. To locate this information, open State Change Events in Health Explorer for the monitor. Right-click the alert, point to Open, and then click Health Explorer. In Health Explorer, click the State Change Events tab. The Details pane in the State Change Events tab shows you when the state for the monitor changed, and the details give you information for the context of the state change.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: (Deprecated) Monitor: The Root Connector has received bad packets which have been dropped. There is no user action that can be taken for this problem, so this monitor is disabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Root Connector has received bad packets which have been dropped. There is no user action that can be taken for this problem, so this monitor is disabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor remotely connects from each collection management server to the remote management server to verify that the remote management server is functioning correctly.
An error indicates that a test failed when connecting to the remote management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor must be overridden to provide configuration of the remote management server to connect to.
The Operations Manager Command Shell must be installed on the remote management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen when:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The remote management server is not available (e.g. the server is not reachable via the network).
The Data Access service on the remote management server is stopped.
The account used to connect to the remote management server does not have the right access.
The remote management server is available, but the test exceeded the default timeout value of 30 seconds. This can be overridden as necessary.
The Operations Manager Command Shell is not installed on the remote management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ping the remote management server to ensure that it is available from the collection management server where this alert was raised from.
If that is successful, check that the Data Access service is actually running on the remote management server.
Check that the Action Account being used does have the correct permissions to the remote management server.
Ensure that the Operations Manager Command Shell is installed on the remote management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The All Management Servers Resource Pool has failed to report as available for some time.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Majority of Collection Management Servers are not running.
Majority of Collection Management Servers have lost network connection
Majority of Collection Management Servers are placed into Maintenance Mode
The System Center Management Health Services on majority of the Collection Management Servers have been stopped.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To further investigate the issue, consider the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Review the Operations Manager event log on each of the Management Servers for events with the source HealthService that indicate problems with the System Center Management Service.
Restart the System Center Management Service on any Management Servers showing an error.
Confirm that all Management Servers have a connection to the database.
Confirm that all Management Servers have a connection to each of the other Management Servers

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Data Access service is unable to log audit events to the security event log.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to insufficient user rights for the Data Access service account.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Steps to fix this problem: 1) Open the "Local Security Policy" MMC snap-in. 2) Go to Local Policies -> User Rights Assignment. 3) Double-click "Generate Security Audits". 4) Add the Data Access service account to the list of accounts allowed to generate security audits. 5) Restart the Data Access service.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor changes state when the System Center Management Health Service has either failed to publish its public key to a management group in order to receive secure messages or it has received a secure message encrypted with the wrong public key.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the System Center Management Health Service, within 6 hours, receives at least 10 occurrences of event that indicates the wrong key (7004), failure to publish key (7005), or expiring public key (7013)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state automatically every 6 hours.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The warning state can indicate the following may be happening on the agent:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service received a secure message from a management group which was encrypted using the wrong public key.
The System Center Management Health Service was unable to publish its public key to a management group and will be unable to receive secure messages until this key is published.
The key pair that the System Center Management Health Service uses to receive secure messages from a management group is expiring.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: No action required - the System Center Management Health Service will automatically fix the problem by doing one of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service will discard the secure message and re-publish the public key.
The System Center Management Health Service will attempt to retry publishing the key.
The System Center Management Health Service will be recycled and the key regenerated.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor and alert indicates that the System Center Management Health Service has downloaded a new action account with an invalid type.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Warning state: Transition to warning state if the System Center Management Health Service receives a new action account with an invalid type (7010)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service processed all security configuration successfully (7023).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The warning state can indicate the following may be happening on the agent:

The System Center Management Health Service has downloaded new configuration for a management group, and that configuration has specified a new action account, but the account is not of type 'Action Account' or 'Windows Credential'. The new action account has been ignored by the System Center Management Health Service as it would significantly impact monitoring.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Fix the Action Account Run As profile by associating only accounts of type Action Account or Windows Credential.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor and alert indicates that the System Center Management Health Service has downloaded invalid secure configuration or missing action account information.
Below is a summary of the default configuration of this monitor:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Critical state: Transition to critical state if the System Center Management Health Service receives a new action account without credentials (7009) or with blank password (7011), or if the System Center Management Health Service failed to process newly downloaded secure configuration (7022)
Healthy state: Transition to healthy state if the System Center Management Health Service processed all security configurations successfully (7023).

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The critical state can indicate the following may be happening on the agent:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The System Center Management Health Service cannot find the credential for the action account for management group. Monitoring will be significantly impacted.

The System Center Management Health Service has downloaded a new account in a management group, but the password is blank. The System Center Management Health Service does not support managing Windows credentials with blank passwords. The account has not been updated. If this account existed previously, its old password will be used and logon may fail. If this is a new account, the action account will be used instead. The name of the account has been withheld for security purposes.
The System Center Management Health Service has downloaded secure configuration for a management group, and processing the configuration failed.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You can perform the following steps to resolve the problem or to gather data prior to seeking assistance from Microsoft product support:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Ensure proper credentials are entered for all action accounts.
Ensure there are no blank action account password.

Capture all 7### events, save the Operations Manager event log on the agent computer and call Microsoft product support. During the support call, mention the most recent 7### events and any error codes (e.g. event 7022) inside the event and ask if the Operations Manager event log is needed.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An agent is attempting to communicate with a management group that does not exist on this management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The agent is not configured correctly. Either the agent has outdated or inaccurate configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Remove the management group from the agent. If the management group is valid, re-install the agent with the correct management group information.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to check the state of a service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A rule or monitor tried to check the state of a service but failed to do so. This could be due to a number of reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The service does not exist on the computer
The Agent action account does not have permissions to check the service
The rule or monitor is misconfigured

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated alert context.
Check the rule or monitor name, also check the detailed information about what the error was.
Ensure that the service exists on the computer.
Ensure that the agent action account has permissions on the computer
Check the rule or monitor (workflow name) to ensure that it is properly configured.
The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with service related events:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An alert from this monitor and a critical state indicate that SQL Broker is misconfigured for the Operations Manager Operational Database. Please see the Resolutions section on how to remediate this condition.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by someone disabling SQL Broker for the Operations Manager Operational Database or a configuration error.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Follow the below steps to remediate this problem.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Stop the following services on the Management Server: OMSDK, OMCFG, HealthService
Open SQL Studio
Connect to the server that hosts the Operations Manager Operational Database
Create a new query
Type "ALTER DATABASE OperationsManager SET ENABLE_BROKER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE;"
Execute this query
If the query is successful, you should see a return value of "0"
Start the following services on the Management Server: OMSDK, OMCFG, HealthService
Wait until the monitor runs again, or force the monitor to recalculate.
The state should return to Healthy and the alert should be autoresolved.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks each instance of a connected management group that has been configured and attempts to connect to each one to verify that its Data Access service is available and taking connections.
If this monitor is in an unhealthy state, it may indicate a problem with this management group connecting to that management group

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor requires that the monitor has the appropriate permissions to connect to that Connected Management Group.
This monitor also requires PowerShell and the Operations Manager Command Shell option to be installed.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If this monitor is unable to verify connectivity to the connected management group, try the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Ping the management server computer in the connected management group
If that succeeds, check the OMSDK service running on the connected management group's management server. If it is not running, connections cannot be made
If the OMSDK service is not running on the connected management group, start it.

If you are still getting errors, verify that the Action Account on this management group actually has access on the connected management group. You can also associate a Run As account to the "Connected Management Group Account" Run As profile.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to run a WMI query or script related to WMI events.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The possible causes for this are:
Operations Manager failed to connect to the computer or namespace. This could be due to permissions issues or that an invalid WMI namespace is used.
Operations Manager failed to run the WMI query. This could be due to permissions or an invalid WMI query.

If the WMI failure is occurring on a computer running Windows Server 2008, it may be due to a known issue with WMI described in Knowledge Base article 958807(http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=133791).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated alert context.
The alert context will detail whether this was a connection, permission or query issue.
If it is a connections issue, ensure that DCOM is enabled

maml:listItem.maml:para: Run Dcomcnfg.exe
Click the Component Services node under Console Root
Open the Computers folder
For the local computer, right-click My Computer, and then click Properties
For a remote computer, right-click the Computers folder, point to New and then click Computer
Type the computer name
Right-click the computer name, and then click Properties
Click the Default Properties tab
Click to select (or click to clear) the “Enable Distributed COM on this Computer” check box
Set Default Authentication Level to Connect
Set Default Impersonation Level to Identify

maml:section.maml:para: If it’s a permissions issue, ensure that the Operations Manager RunAs account has the appropriate permissions to access WMI.
If it’s a query issue, examine the rule or monitor that contains the WMI script and take appropriate action by modifying it.
You should also review the details provided in Knowledge Base article 958807 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=133791). If the update is applicable, apply it to this computer.
The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the WMI Event component:

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting WMI problems, go to http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158224.

You can also download the WMI Diagnosis Utility at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158226. The WMI Diagnosis Utility is a VBScript script designed to help you troubleshoot the current state of the WMI service on a computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The WMI Event module retrieved a data item with a very large array.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The WMI Event module retrieved a data item with a very large array. This can result in very long processing times and large memory usage.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: You should consider modifying the query string that returned the large array entry, if possible. More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the WMI Event module:

maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects event data that will be used in either reporting or a view.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Operations Manager failed to run a WMI query.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: If the WMI failure is occurring on a computer running Windows Server 2008, it may be due to a known issue with WMI described in Knowledge Base article 958807 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=133791).

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: More details of what caused this issue can be found by examining the associated event. The following link will display all events indicating a possible problem with the WMI Probe module:
Review the details provided in Knowledge Base article 958807 (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=133791). If the update is applicable, apply it to this computer.
Some common issues with WMI can be resolved by performing the following steps:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Apply the hotfix from Knowledge Base article 933061, "A hotfix is available that improves the stability of the Windows Management Instrumentation repository in Windows Server 2003" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=180727).

Apply the hotfix from Knowledge Base article 955360, "WSH binaries are overwritten by Windows File Protection after you install Windows Script 5.7 on a computer that is running Windows Server 2003 or Windows XP" (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=180728). This updates the Windows Scripting Host (cscript) to version 5.7.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting WMI problems, go to http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158224.

You can also download the WMI Diagnosis Utility at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158226. The WMI Diagnosis Utility is a VBScript script designed to help you troubleshoot the current state of the WMI service on a computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One of the Web Server Management modules detected an unsupported version of Windows Remote Management. As a result, the current request will not be processed successfully.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The failure may have happened due to unavailability of latest hotfixes and service packs.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The resolution of this failure is to install latest updates for Windows Remote Management. See http://support.microsoft.com/kb/KB936059 for more info.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Windows Workflow 4.0 module experienced a runtime error.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Windows Workflow 4.0 module can fail during runtime in the following cases: The runtime duration exceeded the configured timeout value. The queue for Windows Workflows is filled with other workflows and the maximum wait time has expired. There was a problem saving state configuration, logging or progress data or something completely unexpected happened.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If the runtime duration exceeded the configured timeout value try changing the timeout value and rerun the Windows Workflow again.
If the Widows Workflow module expired due to the queue being full check the system to understand what other Windows Workflows are in the queue and then rerun the Windows Workflow again.

If there was a problem saving state configuration, logging or progress data or something completely unexpected happened check the agent or management server configuration, ensure .Net Framework 4.0 is installed and rerun the Windows Workflow again.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A workflow running the Windows Workflow 4.0 module has experienced a problem initializing.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This could be caused due to invalid configuration being passed into the module or a problem with loading a dependent assembly or type.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the configuration of the module and try to rerun the workflow again.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rolls up performance health of the Alert Subscription Module

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rolls up the overall availability health of the Alert Subscription Data Source Module. The individual unit monitors below this monitor will have state and knowledge when there are problems with Alert Subscriptions.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Generation of notification is delayed due to overloaded resources causing acknowledgements for Notifications to take longer than expected. Acknowledgements are received when the Notification subsystem generates notification based on a subscription. The acknowledgements have slowed down identifying an overall slowing of the subsystem.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Notifications Server has slowed down and is unable to keep up with the generation of notifications for the alerts raised. The acknowledgements on the sending of notifications through the channels have slowed down. This may happen due to
1. Alert storms - too many alerts have been generated than can be handled by the Notification server in reasonable time period.
2. Operations DB is overloaded and has caused overall system slow down.

The Notification acknowledgements can slow down usually because the Notifications Resource Pool, and its member Management server that has the Notification subsystem is overloaded. It is possible that the Operations database is under heavy load or the resources are being exhausted.

If these alerts are generated during or shortly after installation of the Data Warehouse or reporting components likely cause is due to the opening the flow of alerts and state transitions to the DW. However, the corresponding data structures are not there yet since Data Warehouse did not deploy its components as of yet. Deployment happens within ~30 minutes of installation.

While deployment is not yet done, data will be retained by alert and state sync workflows to be later written to the DW. Thus, these workflows do not put data back to data sources and that in turn generates the alerts in question. Once deployment is complete, data is written and alerts clear up automatically.
If alerts do not auto-resolve within 120 minutes of Data Warehouse installation then another problem exists.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is taking a long time to generate acknowledgements for notification messages. This is due to slowing down of the lack of resources available to the Notification subsystem.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Note the high and low watermarks for the Notification subsystem. These indicate the extents of the Alerts data in the Operations Database that is being processed.

Check the subscriptions in the Management group. If there are any subscriptions that have complex queries associated with it they can slow down the generation of all notifications. See if you can simplify the criteria for the alert.
You may have too many subscriptions. Check if you can disable or delete unnecessary subscriptions.
The computer hosting the Operations Database may not have sufficient resources. Diagnose the resources hardware and software that are being over utilized. Adding more resources could ease the load.
Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps.

maml:section.maml:para: 1. Check the Alerts view for newly created Alerts. If there are too many alerts being generated, identify the root cause of the alerts and fix it.
2. If the Alerts cannot be stopped, disable the Alert generation on the monitor until the rate of Alerts can be controlled.

3. If all the notifications about the same Alert, identify the subscription that is causing the Notification and disable it. The Subscription ID of the subscription behind the notification can usually be found in the body of the notification message.
4. The Operations DB or the machine hosting it may be overloaded. Please use Operations Database diagnostic steps to verify if these problems can be fixed.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more alert notification subscriptions encountered an error while attempting to run. Some or all notifications may not be correctly delivered.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert criteria selected for the Subscription may be returning an error when used to filter Alerts in the Operations database. The Operations database has errors and hence maybe causing the wrong information to be sent to Reporting server. It is possible that the state of Notification subsystem is corrupted and it cannot read or write the state of this notification. Notification subsystem was unable to generate a notification message due to errors in the Notification runtime.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is unable to generate notification messages due to availability problems. This may be due to one of many reasons.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the subscriptions in the Management group. If there are any subscriptions that have complex queries associated with it they can slow down the generation of all notifications. See if you can simplify the criteria for the alert.
Check if the subscription information has been set correctly.
Validate any other error messages in the Operations Manager Event logs for problems.

Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps. There may be other failures in the Operations Manager runtime.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration monitor indicates a problem with configuration of the Notification subsystem. The notification configuration may be a corrupted state or is unable to read it from the corrupted state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem was unable to retrieve the state because of database errors. The state is being set from the module configuration. You may see duplicate notifications. Another problem could be that Notification subsystem was not able to read the state information. Notification subsystem was unable to read time zone information and reverted to UTC.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is unable to generate notification messages due to configuration problems. This may be due to one of many reasons.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check if the subscription information has been set correctly.
Check to make sure your Operations Manager and especially the Notification subsystem is configured correctly.

Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps. There may be other failures in the Operations Manager runtime.
The subscription might be missing time zone information. The Notification subsystem has reverted back to using UTC for displaying time sensitive fields in the notification messages.
Backup and recreate your subscriptions for Operations Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor tracks the performance of the queries that select Alerts matching the subscription criteria. If these queries are too slow it could result in delay of notifications sent out by the Notification subsystem.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert queries can slow down usually because the Query processor in SQL Database is overloaded. IT is possible that the Operations database is under heavy load. If the alert query is complex it can slow down processing of the query.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is taking a long time to generate notification messages. This is due to slowing down of the query processing used to match alert criteria presented in the subscription against the alerts in the Operations database.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Note the high and low watermark information associated with Notification subsystem. These indicate the extents of the Alerts data in the Operations database that is being processed.
Verify that the SQL query engine is not overloaded with many queries.

Check the subscriptions in the Management group. If there are any subscriptions that have complex queries associated with it they can slow down the generation of all notifications. See if you can simplify the criteria for the alert.
You may have too many subscriptions. Check if you can disable or delete unnecessary subscriptions.
The computer hosting the Operations Database may not have sufficient resources. Diagnose the resources hardware and software that are being over utilized. Adding more resources could ease the load.
Many alerts may be getting generated in the system as a result of the alert storm. Turn off notification while Alerts can be tuned.
Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The WMI health monitor tried to run the WMI query “select * from win32_operatingsystem” and encountered a WMI error.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: WMI on this computer is unhealthy and cannot return any data from the query.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) service is running on this computer.
Ensure that the Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service is running on this computer.
Ensure that the WMI Repository is consistent on the computer

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open a Command Prompt
Run the following command: “winmgmt /verifyrepository”
If the repository is not consistent, then run the command “winmgmt /salvagerepository”

maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that DCOM is enabled

maml:listItem.maml:para: Run Dcomcnfg.exe
Click the Component Services node under Console Root
Open the Computers folder
For the local computer, right-click My Computer, and then click Properties
For a remote computer, right-click the Computers folder, point to New and then click Computer
Type the computer name
Right-click the computer name, and then click Properties
Click the Default Properties tab
Click to select (or click to clear) the “Enable Distributed COM on this Computer” check box
Set Default Authentication Level to Connect
Set Default Impersonation Level to Identify

maml:section.maml:para: If none of these steps resolve the issue, you can download the WMI Diagnosis Utility at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158226.The WMI Diagnosis Utility is a VBScript script designed to help you troubleshoot the current state of the WMI service on a computer.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting WMI problems, go to http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158224.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The WMI service on this computer is using too much memory.

This monitor periodically checks the total memory usage of WMI on the computer by checking the Private Bytes counter for all process instances starting with WmiPrv and comparing that with 2 thresholds. By default this monitor will go into a warning state if any WMI related process consumes more than 500MB of memory. It will go into an error state if any WMI related process consumes more than 600MB of memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A possible cause is a WMI memory leak, causing WMI to consume more and more memory over time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you see a pattern of WMI memory issues, this monitor has a disabled recovery that will automatically restart WMI when the warning or error threshold is exceeded. If you see that this resolves the issue, you can enable one of those recoveries.

maml:section.maml:title: External
maml:section.maml:para: For more information on troubleshooting WMI problems, go to http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158224.

You can also download the WMI Diagnosis Utility at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=158226. The WMI Diagnosis Utility is a VBScript script designed to help you troubleshoot the WMI service on a computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Warning rule indicates a problem with configuration of the Notification subsystem. The notification configuration may be a corrupted state or is unable to read it from the corrupted state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem was unable to retrieve the state because of database errors. The state is being set from the module configuration. You may see duplicate notifications. Another problem could be that Notification subsystem was not able to read the state information. Notification subsystem was unable to read time zone information and reverted to UTC.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is unable to generate notification messages due to configuration problems. This may be due to one of many reasons.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check if the subscription information has been set correctly.
Check to make sure your Operations Manager and especially the Notification subsystem is configured correctly.

Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps. There may be other failures in the Operations Manager runtime.
The subscription might be missing time zone information. The Notification subsystem has reverted back to using UTC for displaying time sensitive fields in the notification messages.
Backup and recreate your subscriptions for Operations Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Configuration Error rule indicates a problem with configuration of the Notification subsystem. The notification configuration may be a corrupted state or is unable to read it from the corrupted state.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem was unable to retrieve the state because of database errors. The state is being set from the module configuration. You may see duplicate notifications. Another problem could be that Notification subsystem was not able to read the state information. Notification subsystem was unable to read time zone information and reverted to UTC.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is unable to generate notification messages due to configuration problems. This may be due to one of many reasons.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check if the subscription information has been set correctly.
Check to make sure your Operations Manager and especially the Notification subsystem is configured correctly.

Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps. There may be other failures in the Operations Manager runtime.
The subscription might be missing time zone information. The Notification subsystem has reverted back to using UTC for displaying time sensitive fields in the notification messages.
Backup and recreate your subscriptions for Operations Manager.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: One or more alert notification subscriptions encountered an error while attempting to run. Some or all notifications may not be correctly delivered.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Alert criteria selected for the Subscription may be returning an error when used to filter Alerts in the Operations database. The Operations database has errors and hence maybe causing the wrong information to be sent to Reporting server. It is possible that the state of Notification subsystem is corrupted and it cannot read or write the state of this notification. Notification subsystem was unable to generate a notification message due to errors in the Notification runtime.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Notification subsystem is unable to generate notification messages due to availability problems. This may be due to one of many reasons.

maml:listItem.maml:para: Check the subscriptions in the Management group. If there are any subscriptions that have complex queries associated with it they can slow down the generation of all notifications. See if you can simplify the criteria for the alert.
Check if the subscription information has been set correctly.
Validate any other error messages in the Operations Manager Event logs for problems.

Inspect the messages in the Operations Manager event log. Other indications of problems in the system may direct you to further diagnostic steps. There may be other failures in the Operations Manager runtime.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: There is a process that runs on a regular basis to confirm that all alert subscriptions in the management group are configured correctly and that their configuration is still valid. If one or more subscriptions are found with invalid configuration then the subscription is automatically disabled and this rule will generate an alert.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The accounts that was used to create the subscription, which has been disabled, has experienced one of the following changes:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The account has been disabled or has been deleted entirely.

The account has had its user role membership(s) changed in the management group, or the scope of the user role(s) that the account is a member of has changed in such a way that the user no longer has permissions to some objects that the subscription applies to.
From the alert description, copy the subscription's internal name.
Using either the Operations Console or the Export-ManagementPack cmdlet, export the management pack named "Notifications Internal Library" to an unsealed XML file.
Open the unsealed XML file with an editor of your choice, and search for the rule that has the same "ID" as the subscription's internal name that was copied earlier.

In the rule's configuration, find the value that is used for the "UserSid". This is the security identifier of the account that created the subscription and currently it either does not existing in Active Directory or the account is disabled. Copy this SID.

Replace this SID with the security identifier of a different user account. This account must exist in Active Directory, it must not be disabled and it must be a member of the "Operations Manager Administrators" user role in the management group.
Consider searching the entire file for any references to the invalid account's SID and replacing them with the SID of the new user account, as well.
Save the changes to the unsealed XML file and then import the management pack back into the management group.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health from WMI service availability monitor that detect non-healthy conditions of the agents.
Navigate through the Health Explorer Unit Monitors that have the warning or critical state to see the state change information and specific knowledge to help troubleshoot problems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor rolls up health from wmi service availability monitor that detect non-healthy conditions of the agents.
Navigate through the Health Explorer Unit Monitors that have the warning or critical state to see the state change information and specific knowledge to help troubleshoot problems.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The monitor checks the state of the WMI service to ensure that it is in a "running" state. If that is not the case over multiple checks, then an alert is raised.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To resolve the issue, the WMI service needs to be set to a state of "running" on the system. Take the following steps to resolve the problem:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Run the "Start the WMI Service" task to set the WMI service to a "running" state. If it succeeds then the issue is resolved.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Run the "Start the WMI Service" task to set the WMI service to a "running" state.

maml:listItem.maml:para: If the task fails then review the error message provided in the task details to determine the nature of the failure. Also, review the Application and System event logs on the system to see if there are any warnings or errors related to the WMI service failing.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operations Manager Web Console is unavailable. This was detected by pinging the Web Console URL from the Web Console server. By default, this monitor pings the Web Console URL every 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen if the web site hosting the web console is not accessible or stopped. It can also happen if the Web Console is not properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Try the following troubleshooting steps to attempt to fix the problem:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open your browser to confirm that the Web Console is online
Ensure that the web site hosting the Web Console is running
Run "aspnet_regiis -i -enable" to ensure that the Web Console is properly registered.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Reporting Console is unavailable. This was detected by pinging the reporting URL from the reporting server. By default, this monitor pings the reporting URL every 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can happen if the web site hosting the reporting URL is not accessible or stopped.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Try the following troubleshooting steps to attempt to fix the problem:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open your browser to confirm that the reporting URL is online.
Ensure that the web site hosting the reporting URL is running

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Network Monitoring targets are experiencing excessive timeouts.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Network Monitoring timeouts can indicate an issue with SNMP credentials supplied, intermittent network latency or unexpected blockage of SNMP traffic.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check to ensure your SNMP credentials supplied during Network Discovery are still valid. Ensure firewall rules are not blocking SNMP access to the devices being monitored. Contact your network administrator for additional troubleshooting.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor measures the Health Service Management Groups\Send Queue % Used and generates the following states:

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: This can be caused by a low bandwidth or high latency connection from this System Center Management Health Service to its parent Management Server. This can also be caused by rules that are collecting more data than the parent Management Server can process; especially when the parent Management Server has many agents reporting to it sending large amounts of data.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check with your network administrators if the network connection from the System Center Management Health Service to the parent Management Servers is saturated. If so, you may need to upgrade your networks to accommodate the traffic.

If you cannot upgrade your network (e.g. if your System Center Management Health Service or Gateway Server is at a remote branch office), you can disable unnecessary collection rules. Below are a list of rule types you can disable and their impact of disabling them:

maml:entry.maml:para: Collects performance data to either the Operational Database, Data Warehouse, or both

When a performance collection rule is disabled, any view that shows that performance data will no longer have data viewable. If the rule was collecting data to the Data Warehouse, reports dependent on that performance will no longer render any data.
Collects event data for diagnosis. In some cases, an event may not be helpful to alert on, but is helpful for either forensic troubleshooting or near real time troubleshooting.

When an event collection rule is disabled, any view that shows that event data will no longer have data viewable. If the rule was collecting data to the Data Warehouse, reports dependent on that event will no longer render any data.

maml:section.maml:para: Lastly, if you still need that data, one other option you can implement in the system to attempt to reduce the amount of data sent over the network is to use optimized performance counter collection rules and event consolidation collection rules. The below table summarizes their benefit and explains how the data is summarized.

maml:entry.maml:para: Only sends the performance data sample if it deviates from the last sample within some percentage. E.g., if the last sample was 42, and the rule was configured to only collect to a new sample with a tolerance of 10%, the next sample will need to 42 +/- 4.2 (e.g. next sample needs to be greater than 46.2 or less than 37.8)

Because only performance data that exceeds the configured tolerance is sent to the Operational Database or Data Warehouse, the data will be less precise. The larger your tolerance, the less the precision.

This type of event collection rule sends the data if one of the parameters it is configured with differs from the last event. E.g., you can configure a consolidated collection rule to consolidate events where the following are identical:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Event Source
Event ID
Source Computer
Description

maml:entry.maml:para: You can then configure a timeframe to consolidate these events (e.g. 10 minutes). If the above criteria match for any event, within that 10 minute window, only 1 event is sent up with its Repeat Count property incremented. If this event was occurring frequently on a single agent, this means there would only be 144 events sent up in a 24 hour period, which may be significantly less than the number of events actually logged to the event log

You need to be aware of which event parameters and properties you consolidate on. Configuring for example on the Description will mean that if the Event Description is typically unique (e.g. it contains a username) then you will still get many events sent up. For that example, you would instead want to consolidate over the Event Parameter that represents the username field.
Also, having a very large consolidation windows has to affects:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Delayed events viewable in the Event View or Reports (since the data needs to be consolidated until the end of that consolidation window)

Slightly higher resource utilization on the agent. With a low number of consolidation rules, this may be negligible. With a large number of these rules types compounded with long consolidation windows, the resource utilization will increase correspondingly.

maml:section.maml:para: See the product help or navigate to the Authoring space in the console to create the type of rules mentioned above.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This module implements a consolidator condition with overridable parameters.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The agent has not reported any performance data into the Operations Manager database for a long time.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para:
This may occur if the agent is unable to communicate with the Operations Manager database, or the agent is unhealthy.
By default, this monitor will alert if the agent has not returned any event data into the Operations Manager database for X minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check whether the agent is able to communicate with the Management server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The agent has not reported any performance data into the Operations Manager database for a long time.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para:
This may occur if the agent is unable to communicate with the Operations Manager database, or the agent is unhealthy.
By default, this monitor will alert if the agent has not returned any performance data into the Operations Manager database for X minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
